GOBal and IDA have agreed to a timetable for gazetting the proposed new Balochistan Farmer Organization Ordinance. While during early project implementation beneficiaries may continue to register their FOs under the 1981 Ordinance, immediately the new ordinance is gazetted all project FOs would come under its jurisdiction. Other project actions to strength FO functional sustainability include the FO and Project Director signing a formal scheme agreement (see para 4.5); after completion of schemes' main works, the project would formally handover responsibility for O&M to FO (para 3.10); and after FO repays its share of capital costs, GOBal would transfer ownership of scheme works to FO (para 4.6). Irrigation Infrastructure 3.9 Minor Irrigation. The project would construct and or rehabilitate about 30 minor irrigation schemes. To the extent possible project staff would select schemes which are clustered in reasonably close proximity to each other (groups of two to five) and near the towns of Zhob, Loralai, Sibi and Khuzdar. Project works would consist of main works, that is, headwork, and all or major portions of main and secondary canals (including structures and offtakes) which PMU would design and construct, and CAD works, that is, any remaining portions of the main or secondary canals and works to deliver water to the farm which PMU/CSG would design but FO construct. Head works or water diversion structures could consist of weirs, infiltration galleries, free intakes or low-lift pumps. The project would not rehabilitate karezes or install tubewells, however, PMU would accept a properly functioning and sustainable kareze (kareze owners can stop tubewell or well sinking in kareze water source area) as a scheme water supply. PMU would determine the cut-off point between main and CAD works by economically analyzing the extent to which it should line the canal system, using contractors and concrete or masonry materials. The point where marginal cost of this lining equals marginal revenue would be the start of CAD works. This point may be on the main or secondary canals. PMU would, however, apply this calculation flexibility so that CAD works do not contain construction beyond FO capabilities. CAD works could consist of constructing or improving canals, division structures and farm off-takes. It could also include some canal lining using alternative materials to concrete, and other measures to improve water management efficiency. From detailed design work already undertaken, CAD works are a little more than 2% of total scheme construction costs. In designing scheme structures, PMU would emphasize functionality, simplicity of design and least cost alternative, including where appropriate, pumps as a water intake. PMU would contract local contractors and farmers (see para 3.6) to construct the main works while FOs would hire or contract local farmers or artisans to construct CAD works.
 - 23 - 3.10 While constructing the main works PMU/CSG would train FO members in O&M techniques. Immediately following main works completion, BID would formally transfer main works O&M responsibilities to FOs, and provide FOs a maintenance manual. A two year "aftercare" period would then commence during which CSG would further train FO members in O&M and water management issues, design CAD works and assist FOs construct them. However, CSG would allow the increased discharges to flow for about a year before undertaking this design to allow farmers to observe and experience the new discharge and decide how to manage it. Based on this experience, farmers could then decide whether to adjust or completely change their water rotation schedule and agree on the CAD works required for proper water management. To allow PMU to undertake the minor irrigation construction, the project would provide civil works, vehicles, equipment, staff, technical assistance, training and operating costs. 3.11 Potable Water Supply. Where possible and needed, the project would provide a PWS along with the minor irrigation works. Criteria for including PWS are: (a) perennial irrigation scheme must have a reliable, clean water source such as a kareze, spring or infiltration gallery so that water requires no treatment to be potable; (b) villages must not have existing improved water supplies; (c) villages must be suppliable by gravity; (d) FO or water-right holders must agree to all community members having access to PWS even during months of peak agricultural water requirements; and (e) community members must want PWS and be prepared to: (i) form WGs who would be responsible, along with a PWS Operation Committee, for assisting to design system layout, undertaking O&M and collecting community O&M contributions; (ii) receive health training in PWS; and (iii) contribute 100% of O&M costs. Based on the nine screening reports so far available, the project could construct PWS at about two-thirds of the minor irrigation scheme sites. 3.12 PMU engineers would design PWSs according to GOBal's current guidelines, that is, a 45 litres/head/day design demand with 20% wastage and 3 % population growth rates, and a 20 year design life. Adding a peak water requirement to the design equal to three times the average requirements means that in year 20 PWS demand as a percentage of the total flow available at the screened sites would vary from about 2.5% to 9.0%. PWS systems would extract water from inside the source (kareze, spring or infiltration gallery) to reduce the risk of contamination, and convey it to villages by gravity through plastic or asbestos cement pipes, usually laid adjacent to the main irrigation channel. The project would provide community stand pipes at suitable points along the pipeline, with a facility to drain waste-water back into the irrigation channel. Any individual villager wanting a PWS house connection would have to pay 100% of the connection costs from the pipeline. The project would construct a dead end connection to the front of the individual's house and equip it with a gate valve and gate valve chamber. The villager would be responsible for any reticulation of the water into his compound or house. In principle the project would connect the public stand pipes directly to the delivery pipeline. However, in certain instances where demand is likely to have pronounced peaks, the project may have to construct buffer reservoirs, which would be kept small to ensure a rapid turnover of water to reduce the risk of the water quality deteriorating. CSG staff would encourage community members to use PWS for drinking only, and not for washing clothes or kitchen gardening. PMU would design clothes washing and animal drinking facilities into the irrigation channel system. To enable PMU implement this component, the project would provide civil works, vehicles, equipment, staff, technical assistance, training and operating costs. 3.13 Pilot Flood Irrigation Schemes. The project would construct four pilot flood irrigation schemes to test the social, technical and economic feasibility of constructing permanent, simple, low cost
 - 24 - flash flood diversion structures which would reduce system maintenance costs and improve diversion efficiency. PMU would design the structures to: (a) enable flood irrigators to utilize small and medium floods while allowing high floods to pass virtually unchecked; (b) reduce and simplify annual maintenance; (c) improve access to river flows during recession of high flows which partially breach diversion structure; and (d) regulate flows into the main conveyance channel to reduce flood damage in the command area, incorporate sediment control measures and improve efficiency of the existing distribution network. 3.14 The main structure is a short weir with an earth bund across the remainder of the river channel. This would control low river flows. The weir is designed so that a medium flood with a two or three year probability could safely pass over it. Larger floods, however, would breach the bund, allowing flood waters to bypass the weir and leave it intact. The diversion structure would also incorporate a head regulator to limit flows into the conveyance channel during high floods, and a sand sluice to reduce sediment ingress and facilitate accumulated silt removal. To minimize construction costs, PMU would contract with FOs to build the earthen structures. 3.15 In selecting the three scheme sites, PMU would follow the same social and equity criteria as para 3.3 mentions, with the additional provision that preferably none, but at the most no more than 5% of the command area farmers should be bonded tenants. The frequency and magnitude of floods would have to be sufficient to justify developing the site, and the overall development must have an estimated 10% ERR or higher, or a strong potential for a 10% ERR. Soils in the command area should have a minimum six foot depth and be fine textured with a moisture holding capacity of at least 18 % by volume. If more than one irrigation can be applied during a season, these moisture holding criteria could be relaxed. As this is a pilot program, PMU would not request farmers to repay any capital costs, however, at completion of construction PMU would hand the scheme over to FO for O&M. Should the structures prove viable, FOs would be expected to continue operating and maintaining them. To enable PMU to implement this component, the project would provide civil works, vehicles, equipment, staff, technical assistance, training and operating costs. 3.16 Status of Engineering. During project preparation studies, BID registered 309 perennial minor irrigation schemes for possible funding under the project. Following initial reconnaissance of 180 schemes, BID staff classified 11 for screening studies, 61 for further consideration and 108 as unsuitable. BID has now completed nine screening studies, and for six of these schemes detailed design including detailed cost estimates and preparation of tender documents. BID staff, with technical assistance funded by GON, will continue to screen schemes and prepare detailed designs up to project commencement, expected around August 1995. BID has also completed detailed feasibility reports for four flood irrigation schemes. Because of the intricacies of flood flows and traditional rules governing water allocations between groups, a screening report presents insufficient information to decide whether to implement a flood scheme. Thus BID has undertaken larger feasibility reports for this purpose. 3.17 Community Contribution. The project would provide for beneficiaries to contribute to the capital costs of minor and mini irrigation schemes, and to the O&M costs of all development works. While beneficiaries would contribute 100% of all O&M costs, they would pay either 15 or 30% of scheme capital costs in real terms depending upon the ability of beneficiaries to pay. The project would use the percentage of scheme service area planted to producing orchard as an indicator of existing average financial returns per cropped ha. Scheme service areas with 2% or less planted to producing orchards
 - 25 - would be considered "low income" areas, and beneficiaries would pay 15 % of capital costs. Beneficiaries from all other service areas (greater than 2% producing orchard) would pay 30% of capital costs. 3.18 Table 3.1 shows beneficiary contributions towards the minor and mini irrigation scheme costs, including timing, form and amount of payments. Beneficiary payments would be linked to specific milestones in the planning and implementation process so that project management could halt development should beneficiaries fail to fulfill their obligations, for example, PMU will not commence scheme detailed design until beneficiaries have deposited the required funds into their CD account. During design and construction, beneficiaries from low income schemes would pay 7% of capital costs, in either cash or labor contributions, but with a minimum of 1 % cash. Following completion of the main works, they would repay another 8 % in cash over about five years. They would start these payments immediately after the second cropping season (that is, one year later) following satisfactory completion of the main works. During this grace period farmers will neither repay capital costs nor pay interest on their unrepaid balances. During design and construction beneficiaries from other schemes would pay 15 % of capital costs, also in either cash or labor contributions, but with a minimum of 9% cash. Following completion of their main works, they would repay another 15% in cash over about six years, including a one year grace period. In both cases, farmer repayments would include a 12% interest rate charge on their unrepaid capital cost balances. 3.19 When beneficiaries contribute their labor to project costs, they will work under a formal contract with PMU. Although their labor will be free, PMU will pay contracted beneficiaries an amount equivalent to the contractor's overhead so they have funds for daily subsistence. FOs would collect all cash capital cost payments and repayments and deposit them into a development fund bank account. The up-front cash payments would be used to mainly finance the main works, but could also be used to finance CAD works. Cash repayments would be used to finance CAD works and high priority community development works including further irrigation works. However, the relevant Deputy Commissioner or his representitive, the relevant BID Executive Engineer, and FO representatives would have to agree to these community development works, and to withdrawals from the development funds to finance them. As beneficiaries would contribute 100% of all irrigation O&M costs, GOBal would exempt them from paying abiana (existing water charges) on their lands within scheme service areas. Strengthening Project Management 3.20 PMU Support. To ensure strong implementing management with multidisciplinary skills, the project would support and expand a PMU within BID to implement the project. The PMU's main objective would be to timely implement the project while ensuring strong community involvement in project planning, implementation and operation. BID originally established the PMU to implement BMIAD, and will retain and reorganize it for this project. To provide greater expertise in community and FO development and training, BID will add to PMU a separate community support group (CSG) which would include four field offices. PMU would have two other main groups, an administration group directly under the Project Director and comprising two sections, Accounts and Administration (AAS) and Management Information Systems (MIS); and an engineering group headed by an Assistant Project Director (BPS'' Grade 19) and comprising another two sections, Planning and Design (PDS) and Construction, Supervision and Coordination (CSCS)(see Chart 1). 1/ Base Pay Scale Grade 19.
 0............. ; I- v 4 - 0 ~ ~ ~ o~ ...... ....... ..- 0~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~0 - NX~ ~ ~ 0. 3~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~.... ..... ....~ ~ ....... -X ... t- 0 0: 5- .... ......-mmmm . -
 - 27 - when GON and KfW funded BMIAD activities finish. Chart 2 and Annex 2, Table 1 show for this project all proposed PMU staff positions, and sources of staff. Internationally and locally recruited consultants would mainly staff PDS, while CSG staff would consist of three main groups, that is: sociologists (men and women) who would act as social or farner organizers and would assist establish, develop and train FOs and WGs; irrigation engineers, trained in water management and development of small farmer irrigation systems who would assist, design, supervise and train farmers when constructing CAD works, undertaking contract works on main works, and operating the irrigation systems during the aftercare period; and agricultural experts and extensionists who would advise and assist farmers with cropping patterns, crop production and crop water requirements. CSG would locate most of its staff in field offices to work directly with the communities. Paras 4.5-4.9 describe in more detail community and CSG interactions. Besides using seconded staff from BID and DOA, PMU would directly hire most of its staff from the local market for the duration of the project. To ensure these staff are quickly in place, and do not have a basis for requesting permanent employment with BID, the internationally recruited consultant firm would recruit, manage and administer most of the directly hired staff for PMU. IDA obtained an assurance from GOBal that by December 31, 1995 PMU would recruit and place all its higher level (BPS-16 and above) seconded staff, that is, from BID a Project Director (BPS-20), Assistant ProjectDirector (BPS-I9), AssistantDirector Finance (BPS-18), fourArea Engineers (BPS-18), and four Junior Engineers (BPS-1 7), and from DOA six Agricultural Officers (BPS-i 7). The project would provide CSG four field offices, located at Zhob, Loralai, Sibi and Pishin. These offices would not be permanent, and CSG would rent buildings for them. Chart 2 and Annex 2, Table 1 show the staff at each field office. Besides CSG staff, CSCS would station its construction supervision engineers at the offices. To assist PMU undertake its implementation responsibilities, the project would provide rented office buildings, furniture, office and field equipment, computers (plus software and air conditioners), vehicles (see Annex 2, Table 2), additional professional and support staff, internationally and locally recruited technical assistance and incremental operating funds. While project management costs are high, not all expenditures allocated to this component are administration and management costs. A considerable proportion are for the design of the irrigation infrastructure. However, these management expenditures reflect the costs of working with small, scattered communities, of attempting to develop sustainable FOs, and of involving FOs in project planning and operation. Institutional Strengthening 3.23 The project would assist BID to commence re-orienting its programs so that it can interact more with local communities and bring them fully into the planning, implementation and operation of minor irrigation development. BID's objective would be to eventually change its role from a constructor of minor irrigation to a supplier of technical services to FOs wishing to construct and rehabilitate minor irrigation. In doing this the project would provide BID resources to: (a) develop a training strategy to transform itself from a traditional engineering, expert department within the civil service to a customer- oriented provider of technical services, perhaps competing in future with commercial consultant firms; (b) implement a series of training courses for all levels of staff; (c) send appropriate staff on international study tours to countries which have encouraged client orientation in irrigation development; (d) implement a hands-on training program for BID staff by undertaking the development of eight mini irrigation schemes; and (e) develop a pilot program to transfer O&M responsibilities from BID to the beneficiaries of all other minor irrigation schemes outside this project and BMIAD. Additionally, BID's relevant circle field staff would be responsible for supervising the construction of one minor irrigation scheme. As project schemes are expected to be in four circles, this would involve a total of four schemes. When
 - 28 - completed, BID and IDA would review and assess the work, and propose further measures to strengthen BID's capabilities to work with communities. 3.24 Training Strategy. BID senior management, assisted by an internationally recruited training expert and with inputs from all staff levels, would develop BID's training strategy. To help develop the strategy, the training expert would undertake an extensive training needs analysis of BID's staff. It is expected that the strategy would include: (a) core training to provide staff skills not normally obtained in their academic studies such as construction supervision and contract administration; (b) professional/primary training to improve staff skills in specific engineering areas such as successful management of groundwater or design of infiltration galleries; (c) strategic management training to facilitate BID's change process to a provider of technical services to FOs. Senior BID management would be encouraged to develop management plans for the future, including a business plan with identified objectives and strategies; (d) specific "customer focus" training to improve staff understanding of customer relationships, agricultural practices, and farmer needs, and the necessity of increasing community consultation to increase farmer input into project planning, design and implementation;and (e) foreign study tours to review successful community irrigation elsewhere. 3.25 Training courses will be provided in varying formats ranging from short on-site individual instruction and short courses in BID's divisions to longer three to five day courses with wider staff representation. - MIS staff will monitor training and training impact. To support the program, the project would provide funds for 15 sm of internationally recruited training experts, 12 workshops, 900 staff days of training courses, and for some 15-18 staff to undertake two week foreign study tours to Mexico, the Philippines and the Dominican Republic. 3.26 Mini Irrigation Schemes. Following the same criteria and operating procedures used for minor irrigation schemes, BID irrigation circle (district) staff would design, contract and supervise construction of eight mini irrigation schemes. This would give them hands-on experience implementing minor irrigation following the project's operating procedures. CSG staff would undertake the necessary social, technical and agricultural development of the beneficiaries, while PMU engineering staff would assist and supervise the field staff's design and construction work. If possible, oni at least two mini schemes, FOs, with CSG assistance, would be responsible for constructing the main works, that is, contracting out the works. The project would provide funds for equipment and civil works. 3.27 Transfer of O&M Responsibilities. PMU, alongwith BID staff, would further develop BID's inventory of minor irrigation schemes. It would undertake a preliminary survey to categorize the schemes by sociological factors, size of works, water flow, irrigated area and extent of rehabilitation required. PMU would then statistically analyze the schemes and select a representative sample for detailed inspection. PMU would develop and implement a pilot program of O&M transfer for some 9 to 12 schemes of various sizes, degrees of deterioration and/or other significant transfer factors. This program would enable BID to further analyze the factors likely to effect the successful design and implementation of a future larger project. To support the program, the project would provide funds for the preliminary survey, and US$1.0 million equivalent to implement the pilot O&M transfer program. The project consultants, particularly the team leader, would assist design the program. PMU may involve the NGO, BRSP, in implementing the program.
 - 29 - Training and Technical Assistance 3.28 Training. Training is integral to the project. It would be directed at three main groups: CSG social, agricultural and engineering staff to train the trainers; FO and WG members to establish viable, sustainable organizations and improve irrigation and agricultural efficiency; and BID staff to change BID work orientation. Except for some foreign study tours to observe sucessful comnmunity irrigation systems, project training is structured around short-term in-service courses. These would mainly consist of workshops and one to five day programs. Staff would do much of the farmner training in the field, particularly in irrigation construction and O&M. BID would internationally recruit training experts who would undertake training need assessments of CSG and BID staff, and then with the assistance of other consultants hired under the project, develop and implement the required training. CSG would use an NGO such as BRSP to train CSG social organizers, FO and WG office bearers and VDAs. CSG's social, agricultural and engineering staff mainly would train community, FO and WG members. While farmer training is difficult to aggregate, Annex 3, Table 1 shows the project's main foreign and local training programs. IDA obtained assurances from GOBal that PMU would: (a) by January 31, 1996 furnish proposals for any NGO-implemented training under the project to IDA for its prior review and approval; (b) by April 30, 1996 under conditions acceptable to IDA, sign a memorandum of understanding with an appropriate NGO to supply training services; and (c) furnish proposals for other training under the project to IDA for its prior review and approval. 3.29 Technical Assistance. To assist PMU in implementing the project, BID would internationally recruit some 173 staff months (snmIR) and locally recruit some 1,009 staff months (smLR) of technical assistance as follows: (a) for CSG: (i) sociologists to assist CSG staff implement their program of selecting suitable communities and establishing and developing sustainable FOs (24 smIR and 40 smLR); (ii) agricultural extensionists (agronomist) to plan and implement agricultural extension, farmer training and on-farm research programs (12 smIR and 36 smLR); (iii) training planner to assist develop training programs for CSG's engineering, agricultural and social development staff, including undertaking training needs analyses (4 smIR); (iv) land and water management specialist to undertake adaptive research, evaluation, development and implementation of alternative techniques for canal lining and water management, plus assist develop water management training programs (19 smIR); and (v) legal expert to review Balochistan 1981 Ordinance and draft a new Balochistan Farmer Organization Ordinance (4 smLR);
 - 30 - (b) for PMU's administration group a monitoring and evaluation expert to assist design and implement appropriate monitoring and impact evaluation systems for all project components (7 smIR); (c) for PMU's engineering group: (i) team leader (irrigation and rural development engineer) to manage the planning and design section and overall technical assistance input, including assisting with a preliminary survey of remaining minor irrigation schemes for which BID undertakes O&M, and developing a pilot program for O&M transfer (60 smIR); (ii) irrigation design engineer/hydrologist (24 smiR) and agricultural economists (8 smIR and 36 smLR) to assist prepare the screening and other studies, undertake detailed design and advise and assist with project implementation; (iii) team to design minor, mini and flood irrigation schemes and PWS systems, consisting of a project manager (32 smLR), design engineers (93 smLR), specialist design engineers (6 smLR), hydrologist (11 smLR), soil scientist (8 smLR), water supply engineer (11 smLR), survey engineers (124 smLR), auto CAD (computer assisted design) technicians (93 smLR), and assistant surveyors (124 smLR); (iv) chief supervising engineer (39 smLR) and site engineers (312 smnLR) to assist supervise construction of works; (v) training experts to undertake a training needs assessment, and assist develop and implement a training strategy and programs to change BID's work orientation (15 smIR); and (vi) experts as required to assist supervise project implementation (20 smLR) and prepare future projects (20 smnLR). 3.30 By July 31, 1995 GOBal through PMU would have internationally recruited a single consultant firm or consortium of firms to supply all the services paragraph 3.29 lists except the consultants to assist with project supervision and the preparation of future projects {para 3.29(c)(vi)}. The firm or consortium should associate itself with a suitable local firm to supply the required locally recruited consultants. If necessary to supply expertise in a particular area, the firm may subcontract a component to an individual or firm or entity. Annex 3, Table 2 lists all technical assistance by PMU section and expertise, and Table 3 lists technical assistance by classification, objectives, activities and outputs. The IDA credit would not become effective until PMU has signed a contract with an internationally recruitedfirm, or consortium offirms, with qualifications and under conditions acceptable to IDA, to supply the services which para 3.29(a) (i-v), (b) and (c) (i-v) lists, and the consultants are on location ready to commence work. IDA obtained an assurance from GOBal that PMU would locally recruit consultants or consultant firms, with qualifications and under conditions acceptable to IDA to supply the services which para 3.29(c) (vi) lists.
 - 31 - Project Phasing 3.31 BID would implement project works during the approximately five years July 1995 to June 30, 2000. Annex 4 shows key dates for activities crucial to project implementation during the first two project years. These activities include undertaking a project launch workshop, recruiting incremental staff, procuring vehicles and equipment, continuing screening studies and detailed design of irrigation schemes, and procuring civil work contractors. Project staff would have consultants in the field by credit effectiveness. As BID would finish constructing minor irrigation schemes during the project's fifth year, these last schemes would still require a two-year aftercare period. This aftercare, however, would be outside the project period which IDA would assist finance. D. Cost Estimates and Financing Cost Estimates 3.32 GOBal would fully implement the project over seven years. The IDA credit would assist finance the project over the first five years. For this period the total estimated project cost is US$38.5 million, of which US$11.9 million is the foreign exchange costs. GOBal with GON assistance would finance all project costs (US$1.5 million) during year six and seven. Project costs are expressed in March 1995 prices, and include duties and taxes estimated at US$2.8 million. Base cost estimates were derived from detailed cost analysis of recent GOBal agency operations (particularly under BMIAD project), including staff training programs, irrigation and other construction contracts and vehicle and equipment purchases. Contract quantities for irrigation works are based on detailed designs for six minor irrigation schemes; on the average quantities required for these six schemes for the remaining 32 irrigation schemes; and on detailed feasibility studies for the three flood irrigation schemes. Contract quantities for building construction come from standard government designs. Consultant service costs are based on recent contracts for similar services in Balochistan and Pakistan. The cost estimates include 10% allowances for physical contingencies on civil works, machinery, equipment, training, and on recurrent O&M costs associated with civil works, materials, equipment, vehicles and other administrative overheads. Additionally, the cost estimates include allowances for price escalations during implementation based on IDA's estimated domestic and foreign inflation rates as shown in Table 3.2. 1 ."osti~ ::::s :3.5 ..9t5. 65 6~3 6.3.... hitemational Costs 1.3 ~~~~~~~~~....... ... . 1. .........6 2.. ........... % 24. PMU would use IDA's standard ICB bidding documents for goods. PMU would procure consultant services and studies (US$0.1 million) according to IDA guidelines for the use of consultants. PMU would also use IDA guidelines when procuring consultants which GON would finance (US$5.4 million). Documents used for inviting proposals, terms of reference for all consultancies and single-source contracts will be subject to prior review for all contracts valued at US$100,000 or more awarded to firms and US$50,000 or more awarded to individuals. Training arrangements (US$0.5 million) would be subject to IDA approval. 3.39 Project Implementing Costs (US$5.3 million). Following normal government procedures, PMU would procure project expenditures on operating and maintenance costs of vehicles, equipment and tools (US$2.3 million) and incremental administrative overheads (US$0.8 million). PMU, and the consultants appointed under the project would procure implementing personnel (direct hire staff) (US$2.2 million) for PMU at local market costs. FOs would 100% finance and procure project recurrent costs, that is, civil works O&M expenditures (US$0.4 million). 3.40 IDA Review. IDA would prior review all documentation before tendering and award for all ICB contracts, all contracts valued at US$200,000 equivalent or more for civil works, and all contracts valued at US$50,000 equivalent or more for goods and training services. These reviews would cover about 70 % of the value of civil works and 85 % of goods and training. Bank staff would selectively post review some 10% of the awarded contracts which are below these threshold levels. Except for CAD works and civil work's O&M, BID's PMU would procure all other civil works and goods under the project. PMU should handle this responsibility well as it had considerable similar procurement experience under BMIAD, and will be staffed by consultants who will prepare tender documents and assist in the overall procurement process. CSG staff would assist FOs implement their procurement responsibilities. Annex 5 shows the project's procurement implementation schedule. F. Disbursements 3.41 The credit would be disbursed over six years, with the credit closing June 30, 2001. There are no standard disbursement profiles for irrigation or natural resource management projects in Pakistan with which to compare the proposed disbursement profile (Annex 1, Table 5). However it is less than the eight years standard disbursement profile for all Pakistan agriculural projects. This is appropriate as the project is small, simple in design, and would be implemented in only one province. 3.42 IDA would disburse credit funds at the following rates for these items:

 - 37 - IV. ORGANIZATION AND MANAGEMENT A. Project Management General 4.1 BID, through its PMU and in association with FOs and DOA, would be responsible for implementing the project. GOBal would establish a project steering committee to determine overall project policy, assist with coordination and regularly review imnplementation. The Additional Chief Secretary, P&D, would chair the committee which would include, among others, the Secretaries of Finance, Irrigation, Agriculture, Livestock, Health and Public Health Engineering, Member, Board of Revenue and the Project Director. The steering committee would meet twice a year, or more often if necessary, and would appove scheme selection, designs, workplans and budgets. PMU would act as the committee's secretariat, and would prepare its agenda and monitor implementation of its decisions. BID's Role 4.2 While BID's Secretary would be ultimately responsible for project operations, PMU's Project Director would be the day-to-day project manager and PMU's three groups, together with FOs, would plan, design and implement the project (paras 3.20-22). To allow PMU undertake its responsibilities, BID would enlarge, strengthen and reorganize it (para 3.20) including seconding senior irrigation and other staff to it (see Annex 2). However, following completion of the final aftercare period (project year seven), BID would disband PMU and bring the responsibilities for community irrigation development back into BID's regular work programs. To prepare for this, PMU's PDS would assist BID's management to formulate and implement a staff training strategy including management and business plans (para 3.24); BID circle staff, with assistance from PMU, would implement eight mini irrigation schemes (para 3.26); and PMU staff would assist BID staff plan and implement a pilot program to transfer O&M responsibilities to FOs (para 3.27). 4.3 PMU would liaise with and be IDA's main contact concerning project implementation, and would monitor overall project progress. It would prepare and submit to IDA half-yearly project reports which would update and assess implementation of project components during the previous six months. PMU and IDA would agree on the report format by end-November 1995, and PMU would forward the reports to IDA within two months from the end of each six-month period, beginning with the semester ending December 31, 1995. PMU would ensure that all credit disbursement applications are sent to IDA. Within six months of credit completion, PMU would contribute to a project implementation completion report, reporting on all aspects of the project. Additionally within this time span, PMU would prepare a plan for the future operation of the project and submit it to IDA. LDA obtained assurances from GOBal that PMU would: (a) within six months of credit completion prepare, under guidelines acceptable to IDA, a plan for the future operation of the project; go) afford IDA the opportunity to exchange views with GOBal on the plan; and (c) implement the plan with due diligence and efficiency, taking into account IDA's comments on implementation. DOA's Role 4.4 DOA will second six of its regular staff to PMU's CSG. These will be agricultural officer level (AO)(BPS-17) extension staff, preferably with horticultural experience. CSG will station them in
 - 38 - its four field offices, and they will be an integral part of CSG's agricultural planning, operations and extension programs. DOA field assistants (FAs) stationed in or near the irrigation scheme areas would assist AOs implement the project's extension program. To enable FAs to be involved in project activities, the project would provide DOA 50 motorcycles, and FAs a travel allowance when visiting project farmers. B. Implementation Scheme Implementation 4.5 Besides scheme development applications already received during project preparation, PMU will advertise the project again in the media immediately after project commencement. PMU's PDA and CSG staff would screen and select suitable community schemes. Selected communities must agree to project conditions, including establishing formal FOs, opening CD and O&M accounts at a local bank and making an initial deposit into the CD account. CSG social organizers would assist communities form and develop their FOs. Concurrently the Project Director and the FO, in the presence of the Deputy Commissioner, would sign a scheme agreement which would detail the obligations and responsibilities of both the project and FO. To ensure both parties enter into this agreement, IDA obtained assurances from GOBal that before proceeding to implement any irrigation scheme, the Project Director and FO, in the presence of the Deputy Commissioner or other appropriate official would sign an agreement which is acceptable to IDA, and which would describe both parties' obligations and responsibilities under the project. Annex 6 shows a draft scheme agreement. 4.6 PDS, in consultation with FO and inputs from CSG, would design scheme works. Following FO approval of the works, and deposit of the required FO member funds in its CD account, PMU would tender and award the main works. Following satisfactory completion of the main works, FO would assume full O&M responsibility for the works. A two year aftercare period would then commence during which FO, with CSG engineering staff assistance, would decide CAD works required and construct them. Additionally, over the five to six years following completion of the main works, in addition to earlier capital cost payments deposited into its CD account, FO would repay another 8 or 15% in real terms of the scheme's capital cost (see paras 3.17-3.19). Following the successful completion of these payments, BID would transfer to FO ownership of the constructed works. IDA obtained assurances from GOBal that: (a) PMU, in consultation and agreement with FOs, shall identify, plan and prepare project scheme proposals in a manner and in a form satisfactory to IDA; and (b) when an FO successfully completes its agreed contributions towards scheme capital costs, BID would transfer to it the full ownership rights over the improved headworks and distribution system. Chart 3 shows the implementation schedule for an individual minor irrigation scheme. Social Development Program 4.7 CSG's social development staff would consist of an internationally recruited social scientist (24 sm), a locally recruited social scientist (40 sm), a directly hired farmer organization specialist and two directly hired women social organizers (one senior position, one junior position) in the field support staff at Quetta; and two male farmer (social) organizers (one senior) and one female social organizer at each field office (total of 12 social organizers in field offices). CSG would recruit local women for the field offices, and they would live at home. During scheme screening, the social organizers would explain the project concept, rights and obligations to community leaders and members. To undertake screening
 - 39 - studies, they would live in the community village area for about two weeks and collect data on community population, occupations, wealth and income distribution, water and land rights distribution, occurrence of disputes, existing cropping patterns and yields, livestock ownership, women's tasks, health and so on. When project staff and the community decide to develop a proposed scheme, the social organizers would assist the community establish and operate a formal FO (see para 3.6), and act as an interface between the community and other project and government staff. The social organizers, in particular, would assist FO develop its financial activities concerning scheme financing, cost recovery and O&M. They would help FO organize its members to undertake its responsibilities under the project, for example, receiving training from CSG staff, undertaking PMU contract work, and contracting out CAD works. They would assist FO members with dispute mediation. Women social organizers would assist community women establish and operate WGs, provide PWS O&M and health and hygiene training, and organize appropriate agricultural training for women (see para 3.7). The social organizers, along with other CSG staff, would be involved in project monitoring. The internationally recruited social scientist, along with the senior women social organizer, would lead, plan and supervise the team's program. At project commencement, an NGO such as BRSP would train the social organizers (both male and female) in group formation, social assessment and other aspects of their work. Water Management Program 4.8 CSG's water management team would consist of an internationally recruited land and water management specialist (19 sm) and, directly hired, a senior water management engineer and two CAD design engineers, in the field support staff at Quetta; and one water management and one farmer support engineer in each field office. During the scheme aftercare period, the field office water management engineer would advise and assist FO members identify the CAD works required to handle the increased discharges from the improved main works. He/she would undertake trials and demonstrations of alternative low-cost canal lining, and improved water management and application methods. The engineer would also train FO members in water management, and O&M of the whole system. The farmer support engineer would assist and supervise FO members in their CAD construction. The CAD design engineers would design the agreed CAD works, while the senior water management engineer would assist, review and supervise the CAD design work. The land and water management specialist would advise on and undertake on-farm research of alternative low-cost canal lining and simple, improved water handling techniques at the canal and field levels. Agricultural Development Program 4.9 CSG's agricultural development staff would consist of an internationally recruited agricultural extension specialist (12 sm), a locally recruited agricultural extension specialist (36 sm), and two directly hired extension subject matter specialists (SMS) in the field support staff at Quetta; six AOs stationed throughout the field offices; some 50 DOA FAs located in or near scheme areas; and some 45- 60 VDAs, one per FO. The internationally recruited agricultural economist located with PDS would assist the team with advice on crop gross margins, crop prices and marketing data, profitability of current and potential cropping patterns and other matters. Immediately at scheme screening and detailed design the agricultural staff (particularly the extension specialist, agricultural economist, SMS and AOs) would meet and discuss with farmers potential best use of additional water, and possible impacts this might have on scheme design. This would, of course, be continued during the first year of aftercare when choice of cropping pattern could strongly dictate CAD works required. Once FO members have decided their cropping patterns, the team would advise them on crop varieties, best appropriate production methods,
 - 40 - harvesting, marketing and storage. The team would stage field days and demonstrations, undertake appropriate on-farm research, and produce suitable extension leaflets, videos or other material. The agricultural extension expert, along with SMSs, would lead, plan and supervise the team's program. After scheme construction, AOs, assisted by FAs, would regularly visit FOs at least monthly and give advice and help and arrange training concerning farmer's priority problems. The team would encourage each FO to nominate a person from their community to be trained to work as a first level extension agent or VDA. VDAs would be the team's main contact with FOs, and should have a positive personality, be respected in the community and be a farmer although in some cases a local school teacher or such person may be suitable. If possible, FO members should remunerate VDA for his services. As stated, BRSP would give VDA their initial training, while the project would provide considerable in-service training for AOs and other team members. C. Monitoring, Evaluation and Supervision 4.10 Monitoring. Monitoring of the project would be "management oriented", that is, designed to provide information to assist internal project management. PMU's MIS section would monitor and analyze project activities at four levels, that is, project inputs (number of staff hired, vehicles, material procured and so on); outputs (headworks, canals, CAD works constructed); effects or success in meeting project objectives (use easily identifiable and measurable indicators such as crop yields or increased orchard or other crops planted); and long-term project impacts such as increased farmer incomes. The internationally recruited monitoring and evaluation (M&E) specialist (7 sm) would assist MIS section, and overall project staff, design and implement appropriate monitoring systems. This would require a meeting of all project management staff to decide what should be monitored, what indicators used, who collects information and who receives, and to set annual work targets. MIS should monitor and analyze long-term project impacts through case studies, not large project-wide surveys. MIS would have a complaints officer to whom FO or community members could bring complaints concerning project implementation, and have them dealt with in a transparent manner. IDA obtained assurances from GOBal that PMU, in accordance with guidelines and on the basis of performance indicators agreed with IDA, would adequately monitor project implementation, and evaluate the achievement of project objectives. 4.11 Project Launch Workshop. To facilitate project start-up, IDA along with BID and PMU would organize and hold a project launch workshop soon after credit signing. The workshop would familiarize implementation staff with project objectives, components and other administrative aspects. 4.12 Evaluation. BID, DOA, IDA (with FAO Country Program staff), BRSP and other appropriate NGOs would undertake two interim evaluations of the project, the first no later than September 30, 1997, and the second by September 30, 1999. IDA obtained assurances from GOBal that BID and DOA, in accordance with terms of reference acceptable to IDA, and jointly with IDA, would undertake two interim evaluations of the project, the first by September 30, 1997, and the second by September 30, 1999, and would produce reports identifying any required changes in project implementation with which project implementing staff would comply. 4.13 IDA Supervision. While IDA would supervise the project at more than average rates during the initial year, from then on IDA would use normal supervision inputs. This higher rate of supervision during project start-up is justified because of the project's importance in initiating GOBal and IDA's new irrigation development strategy. Annex 7 contains IDA's proposed supervision plan, and details the required annual staff inputs and expected skill requirements needed on supervision missions.
 - 41 - The project would provide PMU 20 smLR consultants to assist with supervision and evaluation, and 20 smLR consultants to help prepare a future community irrigation project. During the project's first full implementation year (July 1995 to June 1996), IDA would use approximately 21 sw for all supervision activities, 16 sw in the second year, and about 14-15 sw for each of the remaining years. During supervision IDA staff should pay particular attention to PMU moving quickly to complete all scheme screening and detailed design work, procuring vehicles, equipment and civil works contractors, forming and strengthening FOs, and supplying FOs water management, agricultural extension, and irrigation construction and O&M training services. Annex 7 also contains key indicators of project implementation which supervision missions and PMU staff should monitor. V. AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION, MARKET PROSPECTS, AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS A. Agricultural Production 5.1 The project would increase agricultural production in Balochistan through augmented water supplies to some existing irrigated areas, which would help alleviate deficit crop water requirements, and through an expansion of cropped irrigated area. The scale of this incremental production resulting from developing the 30 minor irrigation schemes was estimated by modelling the production and cropping patterns of a set of representative irrigation schemes based on several schemes recently screened or prepared to detailed design during project preparation. 5.2 On the basis of the modelling exercise (see Implementation Volume, Project Costing and Analysis annex), the project is expected to increase the cropped area under minor irrigation by less than 1,000 ha. The expectation, or target, may be considered to be about 920 ha over the five full years of the project's implementation. Of this area, about 830 ha would be planted in newly established deciduous fruit orchards: 150 ha of mixed orchards, about 510 ha of traditional apple varieties and about 170 ha of semi-dwarf apples. The remaining incremental irrigated areas would be planted in arable food and fodder crops. Together with existing irrigated areas (some 2,140 ha), on which some changes in cropping patterns are expected to combine with yield improvements, the project at full development should to lead to net production increases around 550 tons of fodder, 6,450 tons of arable crops, 3,270 tons of mixed orchard fruits and 14,200 tons of apples. Table 5.1 and Annex 8, Tables 2-6 and 14 show assumed crop yields, cropping patterns for farms at different altitudes, and overall project cropping pattern. Agricultural production from the development of the mini and flood schemes may increase these production estimates by about 20 percent (approximately 500 ha under mini schemes and 1,200 ha under flood schemes). B. Marketing Prospects 5.3 Despite the difficult terrain of the province, marketing networks within Balochistan are surprisingly extensive. It is also a rather sophisticated private-sector operation where purchasing agents, truckers, wholesalers and other middlemen provide a range of fairly well defined differentiated services. State intervention in marketing is limited to the subsidization of some staples and of some agricultural inputs and to regulating the activities of commission agents, but in general the markets are largely free and unregulated. There is also a notable movement of produce into and out of Afghanistan and Iran. Balochistan is a net importer of food.
 - 42 - 5.4 The main marketing policy of the provincial government has centered on the ADB-financed Fruit and Vegetable Marketing Project, which is a national project. Project objectives are to establish an organized fruit and vegetable market, regulate the activities of commission agents through licenses, improve marketing information and undertake research on post harvest technology. The project includes the construction of a new wholesale market in Quetta. 5.5 The project also prompted the introduction of a revised Balochistan Agricultural Produce Markets Act 1991, which replaces the Agricultural Produce Act 1939. The Agricultural Produce Markets Act provides for the regulation of the purchase and sale of agricultural produce and the establishment of markets for agricultural produce in the province. The act aims to improve the administration of local markets in line with other provinces, notably Punjab, and allows the government to exercise limited control over the purchase and sale of produce in a notified area through the issuance of licenses for commission agents, who then come under the supervision of a local marketing committee. 5.6 Actual demand for good quality fresh produce is limited within Balochistan, except for Quetta. Much of the province's fresh produce is sent on to main markets in Sindh and Punjab. The major destinations for Balochistan produce are Faisalabad, Multan, Lahore and Karachi. Dera Ghazi Khan is an important transfer market for produce leaving the area. Transport is normally plentiful and prices are market driven. 5.7 There are normally few storage facilities at the market level. Most produce is held for a limited time by the commission agent and at wholesale markets. The province lacks cold storage facilities for fruits; although, the ADB Fruit and Vegetable Marketing Project may help ease this constraint with the construction of cold storage facilities at Quetta and Lorali. The wholesale marketing of goods is well structured with specialization in the various commodities. The wholesale operation attracts a degree of risk as the wholesalers buy produce often on credit from the commission agent. 5.8 The marketing of fruits is conducted mostly on the basis of contracts to reduce the risk to the farmer and to compensate for limited access to market information, which is a constraint for the more remote areas of the province. The contractor would advance a portion of the expected income from the crop, which might amount to as much as 50%. This arrangement is normally entered into early in the season, and so the contractor in principle bears the risk of any loss or downward fluctuation in price. In some arrangements, the contractor would also be responsible for crop protection measures until harvest. The contractor is normally responsible for labor required for harvesting and for all packaging and transportation to the market. 5.9 Direct marketing by farmers is becoming increasingly popular, partly through improvements in rural telecommunications. The proportion of farmers taking their own produce to market is notably on the rise in the main apple areas around Zhob, Lorali and Ziarat. The marketing of vegetables and melons is similar to the marketing of fruit. In general, however, contract harvesters are not a prominent feature; although in the major vegetable growing areas such as Harnai, contractors do operate. Also, compared to the marketing of fruit, a higher proportion of farmers market their vegetables themselves. This is particularly characteristic of onion producers, who are often prepared to travel from Nushki, close to the border with Iran and Afghanistan, to Lahore if they have a good crop.
 - 43 - 5.10 The growing importance of urban markets in the province is apparent with the specialization of some farmers, particularly in the Pishin district, who produce early tomatoes and other early crops through the growing of seedlings in Sukkur or through the use of plastic green houses. 5.11 The bulk of the grain grown in Balochistan is kept for home consumption. In some areas, however, where sailaba and rain-fed agriculture dominate, wheat is a significant cash crop. The market price is depressed by the government's continuing subsidization of wheat consumption. 5.12 Fodder crops are grown throughout the province, both in perennial and sailaba irrigated land. They provide an important cash crop and are critical for animal husbandry. The market for fodder is substantial in urban areas as a result of dairies and the wide-spread use of draft animals. In particular, there is a substantial market for fodder in the Sibi area and in the Kachhi plains in general. Breeding dairy cows and draft bullocks is an important source of income here. Sibi also lies on the traditional route of nomads who pass from the winter grazing in the Kachhi Plains to the summer grazing in the hills. They frequently buy fodder to supplement the range grazing. Fodder is handled separately from the main fruit and vegetable marketing. Some fodder is grown on a contract basis. This fodder (wheat, barley or oats) is then frequently taken to Quetta. Prices for fodder in the main markets remain fairly constant throughout the year, but may seasonally fluctuate in local markets. 5.13 Balochistan has some minor crops, such as cherries and cumin, which will probably see local expansion. The demand for cherries is increasing with the market and wholesale price rising steeply. In the higher areas, farmers are experimenting with cherries and have planted some substantial areas to the crop around Ziarat. As the crop attracts a high price, it is normally marketed directly by the farmer. The growing of cumin, although not widespread, does form an important income to farmers in areas without much water and may often be their only cash crop. 5.14 In summary, no major difficulties in the marketing of the project's incremental production are foreseen. The markets for apples and other fruits are expected to continue to expand in Karachi and Sindh. The same is expected to be true for the marketing of vegetables. Balochistan has a comparative advantage in providing vegetables off season in other provinces. Moreover, the project's production is not expected to be on a scale to have much of an impact on market prices, either within the province or in its main markets outside. C. Financial Analysis Prices 5.15 For the financial and economic analyses, inputs and outputs have been valued at present and projected (2000 - 2005) prices expressed in March 1995 constant values. The economic analysis estimates the incremental benefits of scheme developments in terms of production-efficiency measures of opportunity costs to the economy, and uses border prices, at March 1995 value, for major tradeable commodities derived from World Bank projections of cif or fob values adjusted for local handling and transportation costs to the farm gate. The derivation of border prices for major agricultural commodities was based partially on data presented in "Pakistan: Irrigation and Drainage Sector Strategy Review" and adjusted for current prices. and data collected during appraisal. The commodity price projections used were those provided in the World Bank's "Revision of Primary Commodity Price Forecasts and Quarterly Review of Commodity Markets, May 1994". In general, the crop and activities budgets of the analysis
 - 44 - use the average of prices expected to prevail over the period between 1995 and 2005. The border prices for non-tradeable commodities that constitute minor project costs were estimated from current local prices using a Standard Conversion Factor (SCF) of 0.9. The SCF was also used for minor costs of tradeable commodities. The financial wage for casual labor in rural Balochistan was priced at R 56/day, which was considered to be a reasonable estimate of marginal value product. Annex 8, Tables 13a and b show the financial and economic prices used in the financial and economic analysis. 5.16 Crop Budgets and Yields. There are financial and economic versions of crop budgets, and of scheme and project models of the minor irrigation development. The financial version incorporates proposed household cash and labor contributions, project provisions for the scheme investments and household repayments of scheme capital costs in generating net cash flows before and after financing. The economic version proceeds on the basis of economic values of production and inputs as mentioned earlier. 5.17 In the future without the project, the analysis assumed that productivity of existing agriculture would improve over time. Generally, this was reflected in an increase in yields of from 0.5- 1 % a year over the next twenty years. In some cases, future without and future with the project yields are close twenty or twenty-five years from now, but with the project's extension services delivered through its field offices higher production is achieved much sooner than in the future without the project. Table 5.1 summarizes the yield increases assumed in the analysis. In the analysis, the high altitude and mid-altitude irrigation schemes share some horticultural crop models. Some of the highest yield increases are expected to occur in the low altitude areas, where the marginal benefit of additional water for severely stressed crops is considered high. The geographic location of the these schemes, however, will also strongly determine whether communities will actually benefit from the production potential. Note also that semi-dwarf apples start to bear fruit in the fourth year of planting, whereas new traditional apples and mixed orchards begin to bear in year eight of planting. All yields are mission estimates based on field observations and data collected under BMIAD and during project preparation. Details of the production, yields and budgets of the crop models are presented in tables attached to the project working paper on Project Costing and Analysis, June 1994. 5.18 The analysis defined five models of minor perennial irrigation schemes: High Altitude -- Area Expansion Mid-Altitude -- Constant Area Mid-Altitude -- Area Expansion Low Altitude -- Constant Area Low Altitude -- Area Expansion The second and fourth scheme models involve the addition of water on existing cropped areas. Yields improve as crops are less stressed and changes in agronomic practices are introduced through project field services. The remaining models anticipate some expansion of cropped areas. In each of the schemes there is some modification in cropping patterns following the introduction of additional flows of water. Annex 8, Table 14 shows details of total cropping pattern changes.

 - 46 - Farm Incomes 5.19 Impact on Farm Incomes. Average farm incomes from irrigated agriculture are expected to increase by about Rs 11,000 to Rs 20,000 in the medium run and by Rs 11,000 to 65,000 in the long run, measured in March 1995 prices. The "medium run" refers to years eight to ten in a scheme's development. The "long run" is 17 to 20 years into a scheme's development. The greatest change in the long run is expected to occur for mid-altitude schemes, where the dominant cropping pattern shifts from wheat production to horticulture. In the medium run, however, the largest gains in incomes should be seen among the low altitude schemes specializing in off-season vegetable production. 5.20 The estimates of farm income were based on the following household holdings of irrigated land. Sizes vary by scheme and whether additional land is brought under command through the project. The last scheme illustrates the case of villages such as Kunara, where irrigation is at present extremely limited, but can be -- although not cheaply -- much expanded. ,'.:',0,0-,)~ ~~ ~~~.... ....... Farmers on low area schemes and flood irrigation schemes would have large proportional increases in their incomes, which, at a provincial level would improve income distribution and provide support to disadvantaged groups in the community. Financial Rates of Return 5.23 Scheme Financing. In the financial high and mid-altitude scheme budgets of the analysis, households contribute 9 % of the estimated capital costs of main works in cash in the first year of scheme construction. Households also contribute 6% of the cost of the main works in unskilled labor. The number of days this represents was calculated using the rate charged for contracted hires (Rs 78/day). The project, however, will pay the contractor's margin to households for their days of contributed labor. This margin was estimated at Rs 22/day. Households are also expected to repay 15% of the cost of the main works, in real terms. This appears in the budgets in the form of long-term credit that is repaid at 12% interest over 6 years, including one year of grace. The project would carry the remaining capital cost of the main works of each scheme. In the scheme budgets this residual financing appears as part of a grant to households.
 - 48 - 5.24 For the households in the low altitude areas, scheme financing reflected these areas' relatively poor socio-economic conditions. Here, the average cash contribution is expected to be 1 % of the capital cost of main works. The unskilled labor contribution is 6% of main works investment costs, while 8% in real terms will be repaid to BID over five years, including one year of grace. 5.25 In the analysis, FOs are responsible for the financing, in cash and in kind, of CAD works, which are estimated at 2.5 percent of the investment costs of main works. The operation and maintenance of the schemes are solely the responsibility of the participating households. Where scheme investments enable expansions of cropped areas, households will also be liable for the costs of developing and preparing incremental areas of land for agriculture. The analysis used the distribution of schemes as shown in Table 5. 1. 5.26 Financial Results for Schemes. Table 5.5 gives the financial rates of return for farmers with an average area of irrigated land in the various cropping systems. The analysis shows two rates of return, the first and smallest when the farmer has to meet all his development costs, the second when the farmer meets 15 or 30% of the real capital costs of the scheme as proposed under this project. These second financial rates of return, varying from 34 to 99%, should be attractive to farmers. Significant demands are made on household labor not only for their portion of investment costs, but also for the construction of CAD works and, in the cases where cropped area expands, land development. ..:.:.:. . .::::.:::~ a 1 . ~ F n i ci l ~ t f R t . . . ni . . . ..........  - 50 - VI. BENEFITS, ECONOMIC ANALYSIS, ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS AND RISKS A. Benefits and Economic Analysis Benefits 6.1 The main project benefits center around institutional developments and policy improvements in Balochistan's irrigation and drainage sector. The project would develop sustainable FOs which could play an effective role in planning, implementing and operating minor irrigation development. It would change and strength BID's capabilities so it can better interact with communities, provide them more relevant services, and assist them to eventually take full responsibility for developing their minor irrigation resources. The project would ensure that project beneficiaries paid 100% of the irrigation systems O&M charges, and introduce the concept of irrigators paying for the capital costs of schemes. The project would initiate a program which could lead to the beneficiaries of all minor irrigation schemes in Balochistan paying 100% of O&M charges. Under the project, and according to their ability to pay, FO members would contribute either 15 or 30% of the scheme's capital costs. This level of capital costs payment is the first step towards having all irrigators eventually contribute 100% of irrigation capital cost development. 6.2 The project would increase crop yields and agricultural production on some 4,800 ha (see para 5.2), benefiting approximately 7,200 farm families. During construction it would provide additional employment opportunities for local contractors, and skilled and unskilled laborers. Through increasing agricultural production, it would create an additional demand for local farm labor, and for transport and other services. Other smaller project benefits include improvements in health resulting from the incidental provision of potable water supplies accompanying several of the schemes, improvements in village amenities through providing clothes washing and animal drinking facilities in the irrigation channel system, and some improvements in the status of rural women. Finally, the development of strong, sustainable FOs could open further rural development opportunities, for example, these village organizations could be used for other development programs, and they could give communities a stronger voice in requesting government services or organizing better agricultural input supplies and/or commodity marketing services. 6.3 Project Participants. Project participants would be small, remote farming communities. Although those living above 1,300 m grow high value crops, the average irrigated area (0.5 ha) per farm is much smaller than the average irrigated area (4.0 ha) per farm in Balochistan's Indus supplied irrigation area. The general incidence of poverty throughout the project areas would be at least equivalent to the general level in Balochistan's rural population (43%), while the incidence amongst project area communities living below 1,300 m could be greater. Scheme selection criteria would ensure that only communities with generally equitable water and land right distributions would be accepted into project activities. Communities are expected to distribute additional water rights resulting from the project roughly according to existing water rights. Economic Analysis 6.4 Quantified Benefits. Because of the difficulties of quantifying the project's institutional and policy improvement benefits, the economic analysis only considered the incremental agricultural benefits resulting from project investments. Additionally, the analysis only included agricultural benefits
 - 51 - from the 30 minor irrigation schemes. It excluded the mini and flood irrigation schemes as the mini schemes are primarily to provide training opportunities for BID staff, and the flood schemes are a pilot program for which the benefits have yet to be adequately determined. 6.5 Incremental agricultural benefits are derived from modelling the production and cropping patterns of a set of representative irrigation schemes that are based on several recently screened schemes, and on schemes now prepared to detail design. Chapter V, paras 15-18, and Table 5.1 specify or discuss: (a) the five minor irrigation scheme models considered; (b) expected future crop yields with and without the project; and (c) economic prices for farm inputs and outputs. The economic wage for casual labor in Balochistan was derived from the financial wage (see para 5.15) by using a SCF of 0.9. Annex 8, Table 14 shows details of total cropping pattern changes in the without and with project situations, while the project working paper Project Costing and Analysis, June 1994 (project files) gives crop budgets and net agricultural benefit cash flows for each minor irrigation scheme model. 6.6 Investment Costs. Investment costs for the economic analysis include the construction costs of the 30 minor irrigation schemes, 70% of the project's total engineering, administrative and aftercare period costs, and 50% of the community development and support services which PMU would provide. Investment costs also include CAD development costs and all necessary farm development costs such as land clearing, earth moving and land levelling. Costs include physical contingencies, but exclude price contingencies. To convert the financial cost values to economic values (that is, correct for taxes, subsidies and other transfer payments), the various financial investment costs were multiplied by individual conversion factors ranging from 0.82 to 0.88. Annual scheme O&M costs have been added to the investment cost cash flows. 6.7 Environmental Externalities. As paras 6.14-17 state, the project should not have any large adverse environment effects. Consequently, it is not necessary to adjust economic net benefits to account for the effects of environmental externalities. 6.8 Development Period. Following the completion of minor irrigation scheme design, construction would take around 18 months with another 18 months required to design and construct CAD works. Some additional water would be available in year three of construction, but generally full supplies would become available in year four. For high and mid-altitude scheme models, benefits would peak around year 15 (mainly orchard crops grown), while for low altitude models, benefits peak around years seven/eight (only annual crops grown). 6.9 Economic Rates of Return. Using the forgoing assumptions and discounting project costs and benefits over 25 years, the project's ERR for the minor schemes as a whole is estimated at 14%. While this may not be a particularly high ERR, it is acceptable given the high costs of working with remote and scattered communities in Balochistan, and as the sensitivity analysis shows, it appears robust. ERRs for the various irrigation scheme models vary from 6 to 15% (see Table 6.1). Assuming an opportunity cost of capital of 10%, except for the low altitude constant area model, these ERRs are satisfactory. Although this model is expected to have a large proportion of farmers below the poverty line, any scheme with an ERR below 10% should be rejected. Before rejecting a scheme, staff should analyze alternative project designs and operating methods. Because the analyses were unable to incorporate the main project institutional and policy development benefits, it is expected that any scheme with a calculated 10% ERR would have a much higher actual ERR. Deciduous fruit production contributes substantially to the performance of the high and mid-altitude schemes. The performance of
 - 52 - low altitude schemes relies on the production of vegetables. The returns to the low-altitude area expansion scheme stem from a significant expansion of cropped area with the project. The high and mid- altitude cropping systems generally are likely to be the more productive as here farmers have excellent opportunities to grow high value crops. The low-altitude farmers are more dependent on finding a special market niche such as early or late season vegetables or mellons. E -- - -E E . i E.ER-R i. i-i: .E: . 7 7 ...... ........................- . . .. ...E i........ E-EE-EgE-g - -ES-E-E:E:-SArea -ExpKanonEeE E::,. E; Ei 6.10 Sensitivity Analysis. The economic rates of return are reasonably insensitive to delays in benefit flows, increases in project costs, and decreases in expected incremental production benefits. Potential project risks such as ineffective, unsustainable FOs, tribal disputes, weak contractors and a too defuse geographical spread of schemes are most likely to adversely affect the project by lengthening the construction period or increasing construction costs. Of these risks, tribal disputes and weak contractors are most likely to impinge on the project, and their main effect would be to lengthen the construction period. If overall project construction was lengthened by one or two years (that is, benefits lagged by one or two years), then ERR would fall to 13 % or 11 % respectively. While the probability of a one year delay is quite high, say around 40%, the probability of a two year delay is most likely closer to 20%, or less. With regard to construction costs, any increases are likely to fall within a range of 10-15%. As Table 6.2 shows, this would not depress ERR to an unacceptable level. 6.11 Switching Values. Table 6.2 shows the loci of ERR switching values, assuming 10 and 12% opportunity costs of capital. Costs could increase by 40% or benefits decrease by 29% before ERR would fall below 10%, or costs could increase by about 22% or benefits decrease by some 20% before ERR would fall below 12%. As already mentioned (para 6.10), possible cost increases are expected to be below 20%. It is of interest that when project costs are disaggregated, to lower ERR to 10% individual costs could increase as follows: (a) scheme investment costs could rise by 90%; (b) cropping costs by 145 %; (c) investment costs and cropping costs together by 55 %; and (d) engineering, community support and project administration together by 140%.
