 - 54 - 6.12 Benefits could be adversely affected by lower-value cropping patterns, lower crop yields and poor irrigation maintenance. The evaluation assumed quite conservative cropping patterns (in production value) and crop yields, plus the project does much to ensure good O&M of the systems, thus the probability of obtaining expected project benefits is high. The possibility of benefits falling by more than 15% is considered to be quite low. Thus the overall project investments in minor irrigation can be considered acceptable at both a 10 and 12% opportunity cost of capital. 6.13 Project Fiscal Impact. While in the short-run this project would add to GOBal's development expenditures on irrigation, in the long-run it should lead to a reduction in both GOBal's development and recurrent expenditures on irrigation. Under the project, FO members would be responsible for 100% of irrigation scheme O&M costs, and would contribute/repay 15 or 30% of the scheme capital costs. The project's pilot program to transfer O&M responsibilities for all minor irrigation within Balochistan to FOs could eventually lead to a reduction in BID's recurrent expenditures on O&M. As well, this project initiates GOBal's policy to eventually recover 100% of irrigation capital costs from irrigators. This policy would eventually considerably reduce the amount government funds expended on irrigation development. Additionally, FO members would pay local taxes on their incremental agricultural production. B. Environmental Effects 6. 14 According to the provisions of the Bank-Group Operational Directive 4.01 (Environmental Assessment), this project belongs in Category B as regards the nature, magnitude and sensitivity of its possible environmental effects. The following paragraphs list the results of an environmental review'' to assess the significance of possible environmental effects resulting from project activities, and to determine measures to enhance environmental management in the project areas. Project staff will try to identify potential environmental problems during scheme planning, and design appropriate measures to mitigate their effects. If this is not possible, staff will reject any schemes where they consider environmental negative effects outweigh project benefits. Staff will monitor project environmental effects. 6.15 The project would have a beneficial environmental impact on communities health where it provides potable water supplies. Additionally, project staff would train communities in the correct use and handling of potable water so they do not contaminate it. Where irrigation canals pass through villages, staff would consider using pipes to convey the water so villagers do not dump household effluent into it and cause a serious health hazard for farmers, and children who play in the water. While malaria is endemic in Balochistan, to guard against existing or additional water supplies creating breeding habitats for mosquitos which carry the disease, the project would design and use canal structures which are free draining. 6.16 The use of fertilizers in Balochistan (50 kg/ha) on irrigated land is low compared to Europe (400 kg/ha). Even allowing an increase in fertilizer use under the project, the risk of nitrates being leached into groundwater is remote. However, while pesticide use is also low in Balochistan, project farmers are likely to increase their use of them (particularly on orchards), and this poses real risks to both farmer's health through lax handling and spraying procedures, and the public's health through excessive Environmental Impact and Use of Agro-Chemicals, Project Preparation Report, BMIAD-II, Volume 6, Annex XIX
 - 55 - dangerous residues either in or on vegetables and fruit. To minimize these risks, the project extension service would put considerable efforts into training farmers in the correct handling and spraying of pesticides, promoting the use of the least-dangerous chemicals, and minimizing the number of spraying. To the extent possible, extension staff would design and promote integrated pest management programs for the protection of horticultural, and if necessary, other crops. 6.17 As the project will not finance tubewells, it will not contribute to lowering of groundwater levels. As well, under the project farmers generally are not expected to dig wells to augment their main water supply. Where the project improves diversion works, staff will be careful to maintain traditional water rights between different groups or schemes. Staff will also ensure that scheme designs include adequate drainage, flood protection and soil erosion works. C. Risks 6.18 The key issue in the sustainability of the development of the schemes is the role and performance of the FO. If an FO was to operate ineffectively or fail, the implementation of its scheme would likely collapse or deteriorate rapidly for lack of proper routine maintenance. The most likely reasons for FOs failing include traditional leaders perceiving them or WGs threatening their authority, FO office-bearers not fully understanding their roles, and inadequate incentives to keep FO members together. Project staff would need to develop mechanisms for dialogue and consultation between traditional village leaders and FOs and WGs, and would, to the extent possible, involve them in the leadership of these groups. The project's community support services are strongly oriented towards minimizing the possibilities of these issues being destabilizing to FOs or WGs. 6.19 Scheme location and distribution are critical to the overall economic justification of the project. Potentially, there may be several low altitude areas where cropped area can be expanded, but per hectare, returns are higher for higher altitude schemes. If a larger proportion of low altitude schemes than presently proposed are built, the project might be much less economically desirable. The size and proportion of small schemes to large ones also has an expected bearing on the overall economic performance of the project. 6.20 The selection of suitable flood schemes is particularly difficult due to the complex sociology of the areas. Also, in these areas there are particular difficulties in estimating water flow and the market linkages, if not already present on a rudimentary scale, may be slow to develop. The return on the investment in the low altitude and flood scheme areas can be rather respectable since production in these areas would be improving from a very low base. The success of the schemes, however, would depend on the ability of the project to pick schemes with a high annual probability of useable flood flows and low unit cost of development, and provide the required organizational building, extension assistance and engineering services as needed, and the willingness of farmers to accept the improvements afforded by available technologies. 6.21 The geographic spread of the schemes potentially under consideration may complicate project management and add to costs. To some extent, however, these difficulties have been anticipated; the establishment of several field offices under the project should help mitigate logistical difficulties. As well, the project would give preference to suitable schemes which are close to each other, and within reasonable distance of the field offices.
 - 56 - 6.22 The performance of contractors, which was a major constraint to the efficient, early implementation of the BMIADP, could also be a cause for concern. Strict post qualification and selection procedures that have been established in the later stages of BMIADP, along with rigorous monitoring have resulted in a small, but adequate pool of reasonably capable contractors. The risk of poor contractor performance under the present project still exists, but is considered now to have been much reduced. 6.23 FO members may not repay their share of irrigation infrastructure capital costs. Project design, however, is oriented towards encouraging farmers to meet this obligation. Firstly, the project would not accept a scheme for construction until FO members agreed to the repayment of capital costs as delineated in the scheme agreement. FO members would then pay around 50% of their share of capital costs during scheme design and construction. Payments would be linked to specific milestones in the planning and construction process so that project management could halt development should FO members fail to make the necessary payments. After scheme construction, FOs would collect their members' remaining repayments over as short a period as possible, and could bring peer pressure on any defaulters. The local government administration, in agreement with FOs and the local BID Executive Engineer, would use FO repayments for high priority local development expenditures. Thus the use of these funds would remain within the local communities. Finally, GOBal would only transfer ownership of any newly constructed infrastructure to FOs when their members have fully contributed their share of capital costs. VII. AGREEMENTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS 7.1 During negotiations IDA agreed with GOBal on the following points: (a) by December 31, 1995 PMU would recruit and place all its higher level (BPS-16 and above) seconded staff, that is, from BID a Project Director (BPS-20), Assistant Project Director (BPS-19), Assistant Director Finance (BPS-18), four Area Engineers (BPS-18), and four Junior Engineers (BPS-17), and from DOA six Agricultural Officers (BPS-17) (para 3.22); (b) PMU would: (i) by January 31, 1996 furnish proposals for any NGO-implemented training under the project to IDA for its prior review and approval; (ii) by April 30, 1996, under conditions acceptable to IDA, would sign a memorandum of understanding with an appropriate NGO to supply training services; and (iii) furnish proposals for other training under the project to IDA for its prior review and approval (para 3.28); (c) PMU would locally recruit consultants or consultant firms, with qualifications and under conditions acceptable to IDA, to supply the services which para 3.29(c)(vi) lists (para 3.30); (d) BID would: (i) maintain identifiable project accounts which independent auditors, acceptable to IDA and using procedures satisfactory to IDA, would audit annually; (ii) have its auditors issue separate opinions on the project accounts, disbursements from the special account, and SOEs and other supporting documents used as a basis for disbursements from the credit; (iii) provide its auditors unaudited project accounts within three months of the fiscal years' end (by September 30); and (iv) submit an
 - 57 - audited report of project accounts to IDA within nine months of the fiscal years' end (by March 31) (para 3.45); (e) PMU would: (i) within six months of credit completion prepare, under guidelines acceptable to IDA, a plan for the future operation of the project; (ii) afford IDA the opportunity to exchange views with GOBal on the plan; and (iii) implement the plan with due diligence and efficiency, taking into account IDA's comments on implementation (para 4.3); (f) before proceeding to implement any irrigation scheme, the Project Director and FO, in the presence of the Deputy Commissioner or other appropriate official, would sign an agreement, which is acceptable to IDA, and which would describe both parties' obligations and responsibilities under the project (para 4.5); (g) PMU, in consultation and agreement with FOs, shall identify, plan and prepare project scheme proposals in a manner and in a form satisfactory to IDA; and when an FO successfully completes its agreed contributions towards scheme capital costs, BID would transfer to it full ownership rights over the improved headworks and distribution system (para 4.6); (h) PMU, in accordance with guidelines and on the basis of performance indicators agreed with IDA, would adequately monitor project implementation, and evaluate the achievement of project objectives (para 4.10); and (i) BID and DOA, in accordance with terms of reference acceptable to IDA, and jointly with IDA, would undertake two interim evaluations of the project, the first by September 30, 1997, and the second by September 30, 1999, and would produce reports identifying any required changes in project implementation with which project implementing staff would comply (para 4.12). 7.2 The IDA credit would not become effective until: (a) PMU has signed a contract with an internationally recruited firm, or consortium of firms, with qualifications and under conditions acceptable to IDA, to supply the services which para 3.29(a)(i-v), (b) and (c)(i-v) lists, and the consultants are on location ready to commence work (para 3.30); (b) ECNEC has fully approved the project's PC-I and sanctioned project expenditures (para 3.34); and (c) all conditions precedent to the effectiveness of GON's Grant Agreement have been fulfilled, other than effectiveness of IDA's credit agreement (para 3.34). 7.3 With the above assurances and conditions, the project would be suitable for an IDA credit of SDR 18.5 million (US$26.7 million equivalent) on standard terms with a 35 year maturity. The Borrower would be the Islamic Republic of Pakistan.

District, Balochistan (hereinafter called the "Farmer Organization") and witnessed by the Deputy Commissioner .District, Balochistan (hereinafter called the "Deputy Commissioner"). Perennial Irrigation Scheme confonns to the Project selection criteria and the development proposals have been approved by the Govemment of Balochistan and the Intemational Development Association, for implementation under the Project. (b) The farmers have formned a Farmer Organization which has been registered under the appropriate legislation, have opened a bank account for the sole and specific use of the Farner Organization and have deposited the required amount in the account. III NOW IT IS HEREBY AGREED AS FOLLOWS: Article 1 The Project will, subject to the Conditions of Agreement, undertake the planning, design and implementation of the construction works and provide training and support to the Farmer Organization. Article 2 The Farmer Organization will, subject to the Conditions of Agreement, fully participate in the development process, including undertaking the farnner This draft scheme agreement is reproduced only to show what such an agreement would contain. As witness to this Agreement, the Deputy Commissioner confirms acceptance of this role.  - 86- ANNEX 6 Page 5 Conditions of Agreement I Definitions Definitions 1.1 "Construction works" are defined as the physical infrastructure being constructed by the Project. 1.2 "Development process" refers to the complete development package from planning and design, through construction to extension and training. 1.3 "Main contract" means the component of the construction works to be undertaken by a contractor. 1 .4 "Farmer contract" means the discrete component of the construction works to be undertaken by the Farmer Organization. 1.5 "Capital Cost" is the estimated cost of the construction works, based on contractor rates and including an allowance for physical contingencies. 1.6 "Preparation Phase" includes all the planning and design activities prior to the actual tendering of the main contract. 1.7 "Construction Phase" commences with the tendering of the main contract and ends with the final inspection and formal handling over of the scheme and responsibility for the operation and maintenance to the Farmer Organization. 1.8 "Production Phase" refers to the five year period after construction is complete. During the first two years, the Project would offer a broad-based extension and training program. 2. Special Considerations Ownership of System 2.1 The members of the Farmer Organization shall retain full individual ownership rights over the water and the improved headworks and distribution system shall be the property of the Farmer Organization. Exemption from 2.2 Provided always that this Agreement is fully complied with, the Abiana members of the Farmer Organization shall be exempt from the payment of Abiana in respect of land owned or operated by them within the command area of the scheme. 3 Planning, Design and Construction Planning and Design 3.1 The Project shall undertake all surveys and site investigations necessary to prepare the detailed designs for the construction works.
 -8 7- ANNEX 6 Page 6 3.2 The Project shall discuss the layout of the irrigation system with the Farmer Organization and wherever technically and financially feasible the requirements of the Farmer Organization would be incorporated into the design of the improved system. Approval of Detailed 3.3 After preparation of the draft detailed design, representatives from the Design Project and members of the Farrner Organization shall review the design proposals on the ground and agree the alignment of canals, position of all structures, operating criteria of the distribution system and details of any ancillary structures included in the construction works. Any agreed modifications shall be incorporated into the final detailed design which the committee of the Farmer Organization shall approve by signing the final version of the scheme layout drawings. Subsequent changes 3.4 Having approved the detailed design, if the Farmer Organization to Detailed Design subsequently request modifications, then the Project would consider such changes only if they are technically viable and where they can be incorporated without increasing the capital cost of the construction works. Where the changes would increase the overall capital costs, then the Farmer Organization would have to finance, in advance, the full cost of implementing such changes. 3.5 The Project shall inform the Farmer Organization in writing of any modifications to the agreed layout of the irrigation system which may prove necessary during construction due to any unforeseen conditions or obstructions and obtain their written approval for such changes. Construction 3.6 The Project shall implement the construction works using satisfactory quality materials and workmanship to appropriate national and international standards. 4 Farmer Organization General Obligations 4.1 The Farmer Organization shall comply with the requirements of the Balochistan Water Users Ordinance 1981 and any subsequent amendments or new legislation which supersede this ordinance. 4.2 The members of the Farmer Organization shall elect a committee which is empowered to act on their behalf. to sign legally binding documents and to exercise the powers vested in it in the constitution of the organization. A statement to this effect, signed by all the members of the Farmer Organization is given in Appendix A. 4.3 The Farmer Organization shall take full responsibility for the operation and maintenance of the irrigation scheme after the final inspection and joint approval of the completed construction works by the Project and the Farmer Organization.
 - 88 - ANNEX 6 Page 7 4.4 The Farmer Organization are required to contribute towards the capital cost of the construction works and make provision for the cost of the maintenance of the infrastructure once the scheme is complete. Contributions are payable into two separate funds; a Development Fund and a Maintenance Fund. In addition, the Farmer Organization shall be required to contribute to the capital cost of the construction works. 4.5 The Farner Organization shall grant full and free access to the site to the contractor, sub-contractor and Project employees. Where this involves access across property belonging to a third party, the Farmer Organization shall obtain the necessary permission and approval from the landowner. The Project shall after giving 28 days written notice, terrninate the development process if the Farmer Organization fail to provide the necessary access. 4.6 The Farmer Organization shall compensate members and third parties for loss or damage to standing crops, the acquisition of land and any other negative impact resulting from the proposed development. The Farmer Organization shall not be responsible for damage caused by negligence on the part of the contractor or sub-contractor. Nomination of 4.7 The Farmer Organization shall nominate a responsible individual who Representative shall act as the contact person between the organization and the Project. Bank Accounts 4.8 The Farmer Organization shall open separate accounts for the Development Fund and Maintenance Fund at a bank approved by the Project. The committee of the Farmer Organization shall provide the bank with a mandate signed by all the members of the committee detailing the names of those persons who are empowered to sign withdrawal notices and other documents on behalf of the organization. Both accounts shall be in the name of the Farmer Organization and shall be operated in accordance with the constitution of the organization. The operation of the Development Fund account would be subject to a number of conditions and the Farmer Organization Committee are required to sign the letter addressed to the bank where the account is held, given in Appendix B, authorizing them to establish the necessary procedures for compliance with the conditions. A separate signed copy of the letter shall be sent direct to the bank. Development Fund 4.9 The Farmer Organization shall agree to the Project being a cosignatory on the Development Fund account, so that withdrawals, transfers or any other transactions involving access to the funds would require the signature of either of the two named representatives from the Project and the requisite number of signatories required in the mandate described in Clause 4.8. The initial Rs 10,000 instalment shall be transferred to the Development Fund. 4.10 The Project would relinquish all charges over the Development Fund, two years after handing over responsibility for the operation and maintenance of the scheme to the Farmer Organization. The release of funds from the Development
 - 89 - ANNEX 6 Page 8 Fund during the initial two year period would only be permitted for the following reasons: (a) emergency repairs, surpassing the resources available in the Maintenance Fund; or (b) approved development activities such as improvements to the infield irrigation distribution system and village infrastructure. Forfeiture of Monies 4.11 If, after the award of the main contract, the Farmer Organization fail to deposited in the fulfill the obligations set out in this agreement and the separate contract, for the Development Fund farmer construction component of the construction works, then the Farmer Organization would forfeit all monies deposited in the Development Fund as compensation for the costs incurred in terminating the works. The procedure to be adopted in the event of such action being necessary is given in Clause 5.12 and the appeal procedures are detailed in Clauses 5.13 and 5.14. Maintenance Fund 4.12 The Maintenance Fund account would be operated entirely by the Fanner Organization and is intended to provide for the cost of maintaining the infrastructure. The estimated annual maintenance cost is equivalent to 1% of the capital cost and in order to build-up sufficient reserves to finance major repair works in the future, this amount should be paid into the account each year. 5 Farmer Contributions Total Contribution 5.1 The Project applies a two tier level of contribution depending on the farmers ability to pay and .......... has been classified as a ............... scheme with a total contribution level equivalent to ...... of the capital cost of the construction works. Contributions are linked to specific stages in the development process and the financing schedule for .............. is given in Appendix C of this Agreement. Methods of 5.2 Contributions are in the form of cash deposits or through the provisions Contribution of unskilled labor. The method of contribution is defined in all cases except the contributions to the Development and Maintenance Funds during the Construction Phase, where the Farmer Organization have a choice between cash or labor. Development Fund 5.3 The required contribution to the Development Fund is ..... of the capital Contribution cost and contributions shall be made in accordance with the following schedule, where all percentages refer to the capital cost: (a) the initial deposit of Rs 10,000 deposited in a bank at the time of scheme identification shall be transferred into the Development Fund account; (b) . in cash, less the initial deposit of Rs 10,000 prior to commencing the detailed design; (c) ...... in cash, prior to advertising the tender;
 - 90 - ANNEX 6 Page 9 (d) ...... in cash or by the provision of the equivalent value of unskilled labor. Maintenance Fund 5.4 The initial deposit of .... into the Maintenance Fund account shall be Contribution payable either in cash before the end of the construction period or by the provision of unskilled labor of an equivalent value. Capital Contribution 5.5 The Farmer Organization agree to provide unskilled labor free of charge to the value of 4% of the capital cost. Farmer Construction 5.6 The Project shall identify discrete packages of work for the Farmer Component Organization to undertake, which have an unskilled labor component equivalent to the capital contribution plus where applicable the additional labor input to cover the Development and/or Maintenance Fund contributions. The farmer construction component of the construction works would be subject to a separate contract between the Project and the Farmer Organization. Failure to Meet Cash 5.7 Contributions to the Development Fund during the Preparation Phase are Contributions during linked to specific stages in the development process and progress is conditional Preparation Phase on fulfilling targets detailed in Clause 5.3. Whilst no specific time limit for collecting and depositing the required amounts is given, the Project life is only five years and as such there is effectively a cut-off date, after which time it would not be possible to implement the scheme within the life of the Project. The Project shall notify the Farmer Organization at least four months before the due cut-off date and if the monies are not deposited within this period, the development process shall be terminated. Where the process is terminated, the Project would, within a period of 14 days, relinquish its control over the Development Fund account enabling the Farmer Organization to withdraw all monies including any interest which has accrued. Failure to Fulfill 5.8 Where the Farmer Organization has opted to contribute cash to the Labor and/or Cash Development Fund during the construction phase, the full amount shall be Contributions during deposited by the date exactly half-way through the scheduled main contract Construction Phase construction period. If the Farmer Organization fail to deposit the required contribution by the said date, the Project shall inform the Farmer Organization that unless the outstanding monies are deposited within 28 days, action will be taken to terminate the development process.
 - 91 - ANNEX 6 Page 10 5.9 If after the 28 day period, the Farmer Organizations has failed to deposit all outstanding monies in the Development Fund account, the Project shall issue a written notice of intent to terminate the development process after a period of 14 days. 5.10 The separate contract between the Project and the Farmer Organization for the farmer construction component of the construction works includes clauses relating to the work program and actions to be taken in the event of progress falling behind program. If he Farmer Organization fail to comply with the terms and conditions of the contract then there is provision for terminating the construction works and in consequence the development process Recommencing Work 5.11 If after the construction works have been terminated, the Farmer after Terminating Organization wish to recommence the work, then the Farmer Organization shall pay in advance all costs incurred in the termination of the main civil works contract, the re-mobilization and any other costs involved in recommencing the construction works. Confiscation of 5.12 Where the development process has been terminated in accordance with Development Fund Clauses 4.5, 5.9, 5.10 or 8.4, the Project shall notify the Deputy Commissioner, Account Farner Organization and the bank where the Development Fund account is held of their intention to confiscate all monies held in the Development Fund. Appeal Against 5.13 The Fanner Organization would have a period of 28 days from the date Confiscation of of the Project confiscation notice, to appeal in writing to the Deputy Commissioner Development Fund against the notice. If no appeal is submitted then the Farmer Organization would be deemed to have accepted the forfeiture of the monies and the Deputy Commissioner would within a period of 14 days instruct the bank to release the funds to the Project. 5.14 If the Fanner Organization appeal against the confiscation notice, the Deputy Commissioner would decide on the validity of the appeal within a period of 60 days after receipt of the appeal notice and his decision would be final and binding on both parties. Where the appeal is rejected, the Deputy Commissioner would instruct the bank to release the funds to the Project. If the appeal is upheld the Deputy Commissioner would instruct the Project to rescind its confiscation notice. 6 Training and Technical Assistance Extension Support 6.1 The Project shall provide training and support to the Fanner Organization in the following fields: (a) organizational and managerial aspects of the Fanner Organization, including advice on the operation and maintenance of the irrigation infrastructure;
 - 92 - ANNEX 6 Page 11 (b) technical assistance in design and construction of improvements to the infield irrigation distribution system and advice on water management; (c) extension advice on all aspects of irrigated agriculture; and (d) integration of women development issues in the development process. 6.2 The Farmer Organization shall recruit and support an individual who would be trained as the scheme Village Development Agent. The main emphasis of the training would be directed towards agricultural activities and a practical hands-on approach would be adopted. 6.3 During the implementation of the farmer contract, the Project would supervise the construction work and where necessary provide practical training in construction techniques and advice on the day-to-day management and organization of the construction works. 7 Security "No Objection 7.1 Provided there are no extenuating circumstances, the Deputy Commissioner Certificates" shall furnish assistance and all necessary "No Objection Certificates" to the Project and the contractor to facilitate progress of the construction works. Protection of 7.2 The Deputy Commissioner shall advise the Project and the Farmer Personnel and Organization of any security problems which may arise that could effect the Property proposed development and shall endeavor to provide all necessary protection of personnel and property. 8 Settlement of Disputes General Approach 8.1 If a dispute or difference of any kind whatsoever shall arise, every effort shall be made to obtain an amicable settlement between the parties concerned without involving a third party. where such a settlement cannot be reached the use of a conciliator shall be considered. As a final solution the Deputy Commissioner shall be considered. As a final solution the Deputy Commissioner shall be asked to act as arbitrator and his decision shall be binding on both parties. Internal Disputes 8.2 Internal disputes involving land and water rights or other matters directly related to the irrigation scheme shall in the first instance be handled by Fanner Organization with the possible introduction of a conciliator acceptable to both parties. If the matter cannot be resolved, it shall be referred to the Deputy Commissioner and his decision shall be considered final and binding on both parties. Disputes involving 8.3 Disputes arising between the Farner Organization and third parties are
 - 93 - ANNEX 6 Page 12 Third Parties outside the scope of this Agreement and would be resolved in accordance with traditional procedures. However, the Deputy Commissioner would exercise his powers as civil administrator to try and bring the matter to a speedy and satisfactory conclusion. Dispute between 8.4 If a dispute arises between the Farmer Organization and the main civil Farmer Organization works contractor, the matter shall be referred to the designated Engineer in and Contractor writing. On receipt of such a notice, the Engineer shall within a period of 28 days decide on a course of action, which shall be binding on both parties concerned. Under no circumstances shall the Farmer Organization or any of its members attempt to disrupt the construction works and any attempt to do so may result in the termination of the development process. Dispute between 8.5 If a dispute arises between the Farmer Organization and the Project then Farmer Organization every effort shall be made to resolve the matter without reference to a third party. and Project Where an amicable settlement cannot be found, the Project shall advise the Deputy Commissioner of the nature of the dispute and the action taken to resolve the matter and formerly request the Deputy Commissioner to act as arbitrator. On receipt of such a notice, the Deputy Commissioner shall within a period of 60 days undertake an independent investigation and decide on the matter. The decision of the Deputy Commissioner shall be final and binding on both parties.

 ANNEX 7 PAKISTAN BALOCHISTAN COMMUNITY IRRIGATION AND AGRICULTURE PROJECT Supervision Plan and Key Indicators Bank Supervision Input into Key Activities 1. The staff input indicated in the attached Table "Bank Supervision Input into Key Activities" is in addition to the regular supervision needs for the review of progress reports, procurement actions, correspondence and so on. For this project, staff estimate the annual regular supervision input as 4 staff weeks (sw) in the projects first year, 3 sw in the second, and 2 sw for the remaining period. Borrowers Contribution to Supervision 2. Beginning with the semester ending December 31, 1995, BID's PMU will submit six monthly progress reports not later than end-February and end-August each year during project implementation. PMU will be responsible for ensuring that all project components are appropriately monitored, with suitable key indicators selected and regularly measured to give an idea of the project's effects and success in meeting its objectives. 3. The project steering committee would meet at least twice yearly to approve scheme selection, designs, workplans and budgets. It would also regularly review implementation. 4. PMU will be responsible for coordinating and arranging supervision mission itineraries and wrap-up meetings. PMU, DOA, and when appropriate NGO, representatives will accompany IDA staff during supervision missions. The Additional Chief Secretary, P&D, will normally chair the wrap-up meeting. PMU will also arrange, in association with IDA the two project interim evaluation missions, and will prepare GOBal's input into the Project Implementation Completion Report. The project would provide PMU 20 sm of locally recruited consultants to assist with supervision and the interim evaluations. 5. To facilitate project start-up, PMU and IDA would organize a project launch workshop. Key Project Indicators 6. Besides project inputs and outputs, key indicators of project effects or success in meeting project objectives which PMU and supervision missions should monitor include: (a) Forming and Developing Sustainable FOs: (i) whether FOs holding regular meetings; (ii) number of members at FO meetings; (iii) FO bank accounts audited and in order; (iv) FO members up-to-date on payments into bank accounts; (v) whether FO members are up-to-date on training programs; (vi) whether FO has constructed CAD works on schedule; (vii) whether FO members have any major disputes, and number of disputes taking more than three months to solve; (viii) whether new FO Ordinance has been drafted and implemented.
 - 99 - ANNEX 7 Page 2 (b) Develop Self-Sustaining Irrigation Systems with Increased FO Participation in Planning and Construction: (i) number of meetings between PMU staff and FO on main works design; (ii) whether most FO members agreed with main works design; (iii) whether farmers have completed their small contracts and quality of work; (iv) quality of CAD construction; (v) whether FO members have successfully completed irrigation construction and O&M training; (vi) whether FOs are collecting agreed member contributions for O&M; and (vii) quality of FO O&M work. (c) Increase Beneficiaries Incomes and Alleviate Poverty: (i) movement up or down in agricultural yields; (ii) incremental crop or orchard areas planted; (iii) change of cropping patterns into higher value crops; (iv) water flow in certain parts of the system before and after works completed; (v) water losses before and after project works; and (vi) number of days community members employed by contractor. (d) Redefine Governments Role in Minor Irrigation Development and Increase Recovery of Public Expenditures on Irrigation Infrastructure: (i) whether development of BID training strategy is on schedule; (ii) whether BID training implementation is on schedule; (iii) quality of BID future management plans and business plan; (iv) whether BID is implementing eight mini-irrigation schemes on schedule; (v) whether pilot O&M transfer program is on target; and (vi) are FOs up-to-date with capital cost payments into their CD accounts, particularly payments following satisfactory completion of main works.

 - 1ni- ANNEX 8 PAKISTAN BALOCHISTAN COMMUNITY IRRIGATION AND AGRICULTURE PROJECT Project Analysis Scope and Approach I . The main subject of the financial and economic analysis of the project is the performance of the minor irrigation schemes, which represent most of the project's investments in field works and for whose implementation the project's community and field support and engineering services will be chiefly employed. The mini schemes overall represent about 13 percent of project investments in irrigation works, while the pilot flood schemes represent approximately 11 percent. The mini schemes are individually small works, whose financial and economic returns are expected to be comparable to those from minor schemes located in the high productivity farm areas. Although the mini schemes are expected to contribute to an increase in agricultural production, their primary role in the project is to provide training opportunities for improving the technical skills of the Balochistan Irrigation Department. An estimate of the expected return to this institution development has not been attempted. Regarding the flood schemes, as the benefits from such investments have not yet been adequately tested, the pilot component is a trial and not included in the analysis of the rest of the project. The return to the investment for gaining the additional information has not been estimated, but an effort has been made to demonstrate by a calculation separate from the analysis of the project the type of outcome from the trial that would warrant further consideration of future investments in such schemes. 2. Quantifiable Project Benefits. The project benefits of the minor schemes consist primarily of the incremental agricultural production that would result from increased supplies of water on existing cropped areas and from expansions of cropped areas. These benefits are derived from modelling the production and cropping patterns of a set of representative irrigation schemes that are based on several recently screened schemes and on schemes now prepared to detailed design. 3. Non-Quantified/Non-Quantifiable Project Benefits. Apart from incremental agricultural production, some other benefits might be attributed to the project. These include improvements in health resulting from the incidental provision of potable water supplies accompanying several of the schemes, some improvements in the status of rural women, and the multiplier effects of enhanced rural incomes and of private and public saving (such as further improvements to road systems and other infrastructure). If implementation proceeds well, communities should be able to build upon their experience of operating water users' associations to undertake other community-based development initiatives. Such benefits that might also accrue to the project are difficult to quantify and if quantifiable, might well only modestly contribute to the overall attractiveness of the project, but they add to the acceptability of the project. 4. Methodology and Presentation of the Analysis. There are financial and economic versions of crop budgets, and scheme and project models of the minor irrigation scheme development. The financial version incorporates proposed household cash and labor contributions, project provisions for the scheme investments and household payments into a community development fund in generating net cash flows before and after financing.
 - 102- ANNEX 8 Page 2 5. The economic version estimates the incremental benefits of the scheme developments in terms of production-efficiency measures of opportunity costs to the economy and uses border prices, at March 1995 value, for major tradeable commodities derived from World Bank projections of cif or fob values adjusted for local handling and transportation costs to the farm gate. The derivation of border prices for major agricultural commodities was based partially on data presented in "Pakistan: Irrigation and Drainage Sector Strategy Review" and adjusted for current prices. The commodity price projections used were those provided in the World Bank's "Revision of Primary Commodity Price Forecasts and Quarterly Review of Commodity Markets -- May 1994." In general, the crop and activities budgets of the analysis use the average of prices expected to prevail over the period between 1995 and 2005. 6. The border prices for non-tradeable commodities that constitute minor project costs were estimated from current local prices using a Standard Conversion Factor (SCF) of 0.9. The SCF was also used for minor costs of tradeable commodities. 7. The conversion factor for civil works was estimated at 0.82 based on the foreign exchange, local cost and tax content derived for the project costing. 8. The financial wage for casual labour in rural Balochistan was priced at R 56/day, which was considered to be a reasonable estimate of marginal value product. The economic wage was then derived using the SCF. 9. The analysis used 10 percent as the opportunity cost of capital. Estimation of Agricultural Production Improvements 10. Crop Models. In the analysis schemes broadly are of three types: those located in high productivity farm areas, average productivity farm areas and low productivity farm areas. This typology also corresponds to geographically high, mid- and low altitude areas in the province. For the high productivity farm areas, the analysis used crop models for mixed orchards, intercropped vegetables, vegetables, traditional apple orchards, semi-dwarf apple orchards, wheat, maize and fodder to represent agricultural production. Production in average productivity farm areas is depicted with crop models of mixed orchards, intercropped vegetables, vegetables, apples, semi-dwarf apples, wheat, pulses, coarse rice, fodder and lucerne. Crop models of wheat, onions intercropped with cumin, vegetables and watermelon characterize production in low productivity area. 11. In the future without the project, the project assumed that productivity of existing agriculture would improve over time. Generally, this was reflected in an increase in yields of from 0.5-1 percent a year over the next twenty years. In some cases, future without and future with the project yields are close twenty or twenty-five years from now, but with the project's extension services delivered through its field offices higher production is achieved much sooner than in the future without the project. The following table summarizes the yield increases assumed in the analysis.

The high and mid-altitude irrigation schemes use the same high/mid-altitude crop models. Some of the highest yield increases are expected to occur in the low altitude areas, where the marginal benefit of additional water for severely stressed crops is considered high. The geographic location of the these schemes, however, will also strongly determine whether communities will actually benefit from the production potential. Note also that semi-dwarf apples start to bear fruit in the fourth year of planting, whereas new traditional apples and mixed orchards begin to bear in year eight of planting. All yields are mission estimates based on field observations and data collected by BMIAD. Details of the production, yields and budgets of the crop models are presented in tables attached to the text.
 - 104 - ANNEX 8 Page 4 Scheme Models 12. The analysis defines five models of minor perennial irrigation schemes: High Altitude -- Area Expansion Mid-Altitude -- Constant Area Mid-Altitude -- Area Expansion Low Altitude -- Constant Area Low Altitude -- Area Expansion The second and fourth scheme models involve the addition of water on existing cropped areas. Yields improve as crops are less stressed and changes in agronomic practices are introduced through project field services. The remaining models anticipate some expansion of cropped areas. In each of the schemes there is some modification in cropping patterns following the introduction of additional flows of water. 13. The command areas of the schemes are not large. For high altitude areas, the scheme model anticipates on average an expansion in cropped area from 44 to 65 hectares. For the mid-altitude farm areas, the average cropped area is 80 hectares. For mid-altitude -- area expansion schemes the cropped area increases on average from 177 to 227 hectares. In low altitude farm areas the expected cropped area is about 48 hectares for schemes that augment supplies of water; however, one can expect schemes such as Kunara, where cropped area increases significantly from 6 to 103 hectares. 14. X... m:AgM 'M ..... - [ .^ ... .. ...: .......... ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 1~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~X- The analysis anticipates that the areas planted in new mixed orchards in the future with the project will be relatively small compared to areas in new apples. Of the areas planted in new apple orchards, the analysis presumes that no more than a quarter would be planted in the semi-dwarf variety: despite extension efforts and the rapid returns from dwarf variety, acceptance of the crop is expected to proceed gradually over time. Note the prominence of wheat for the mid-altitude schemes without the project. Under the project, households are expected to increase incomes and maximise returns to the use of water by planting more of their irrigated holdings in orchards. 15. Scheme Financing. In the financial high and mid-altitude scheme budgets of the analysis, households contribute 9% of the estimated capital costs of main works in cash during scheme construction. Households also contribute 6% of the cost of the main works in unskilled labor. The number of days this represents is calculated using the rate charged for contracted hires. This rate is estimated at Rs 78/day. The project, however, will pay the contractor's margin to households for their days of contributed labor. Assuming that the ordinary rural wage for unskilled labor will be about Rs 56/day, this margin is estimated at Rs 22/day. This income to households appears in the financial budgets under the heading "Grant including Construction Wages". Households are also expected to repay 15% of the cost of the main works, in real terms, to BID. This appears in the budgets in the form of long-term credit that is repaid at 12% interest over 6 years. The project would carry the remaining capital cost of the main works of each scheme. In the scheme budgets this residual financing appears as part of a grant to households. 16. For the households in the low altitude areas, scheme financing reflects these areas' relatively poor socio-economic conditions. Here, the average cash contribution is expected to be 1% of the capital cost of main works. The unskilled labor contribution is 6% of main works investment costs, while 8% will be repaid to BID. 17. Irrigators will be responsible for the financing, in cash and in kind, of CAD works, which are estimated at 2.5 percent of the investment costs of main works. The operation and maintenance of the schemes are solely the responsibility of the households. Where scheme investments enable expansions of cropped areas, households will also be liable for the costs of developing and preparing incremental areas of land for agriculture.
 - 109 - ANNEX 8 Page 9 18. Supply of Household Labor. The financial budgets of the schemes assumes as a starting point that households at present supply about 90 percent of the farm labor required for cropping. The rest of the labor is hired at the going rural wage. It is also assumed that the availability of household labor will be the same both for the future without and with the project, but growing at 3 percent per annum. 19. Financial and Economic Results. As expected, given the terms of the financing of schemes, the financial internal rates of return after financing are quite strong, but significant demands are made on household labor not only for their portion of investment costs, but also for the construction of CAD works and, in the cases where cropped area expands, land development. The economic rates of return are also satisfactory. Deciduous fruit production contributes substantially to the performance of the high and average productivity farm schemes. The performance of low altitude schemes relies on the production of vegetables. The returns to the second low altitude farm stem from a significant expansion of cropped area with the project. The following table summarizes the results. Detailed budgets are included in SAR working paper "Project Costing and Analysis, June 1994. Average farm incomes from irrigated agriculture are expected to increase by about Rs I 1,000 to Rs 20,000 in the short run and by Rs 11,000 to 65,000 in the long run, measured in March 1995 prices. The "short run" refers to years eight to ten in a scheme's development: just after households have finished paying their cash contributions into their village development fund. The "long run" is 17 to 20 years into a scheme's development. The greatest change in the long run is expected occur for mid-altitude schemes, where the dominant cropping pattern shifts from wheat production to horticulture. In the short run, however, the largest gains in incomes should be seen among the low altitude schemes specializing in off-season vegetable production. 21. The estimates of farm income were based on the following household holdings of irrigated land. Sizes vary by scheme and whether additional land is brought under command through the project.

With these projections, cropped area under the project would increase from 2,130 ha to about 3,050 ha. 26. Allocation of Project Costs. As the project's field services will contribute to objectives other than the development of incremental irrigation water supplies (that is, public health, womens' education, village mobilization for self help), the analysis estimated that perhaps 70 percent of project costs for Community Support could be allocated to the implementation of the minor, mini and flood schemes (the sensitivity analysis of financial and economic indicators will later show that this is not a critical parameter). Of the project's 42 proposed schemes, the minor schemes would absorb about 70 percent of this allocation, assuming that the costs of support services are spread more or less evenly among the schemes. Financial Base "aftercare" costs for the two years following the end of the project period were estimated at about Rs 15,400 and Rs 7,700 from the recurrent expenditures of the project's costings. Following the same procedure, the analysis allocated 70 percent of these costs to the irrigation schemes and about 70 percent of this allocation to the minor schemes. Financial base costs were converted to their economic equivalents using an average conversion factor of 0.88.
 - 112 _ ANNEX 8 Page 12 27. The analysis attributes all of the costs associated with the engineering services of the PMU to the implementation of the irrigation schemes. Given evenly distributed costs among schemes, the minor schemes' share of the engineering services is about 70 percent. The economic analysis converts these costs into their border price equivalents by applying an average conversion factor of 0.88. 28. On the basis of expenditure shares of project costs, the analysis considers that the irrigation works can claim about 93 percent of the costs of project administration to be incurred by the PMU. Of this portion, about 70 percent can be expected to allocated to the minor schemes. The ratio of economic to financial base administrative costs for the economic analysis works out to about 0.83. 29. Returns to the Project (Minor Irrigation Schemes). On the basis of the modelling exercise the project is expected to increase the cropped area under minor irrigation in the province by less than 1000 ha. The expectation, or target, may be considered to be about 920 ha over the 5 full years of the project's implementation. Of this area, about 830 ha would be planted in newly established deciduous fruit orchards: 150 ha of mixed orchards, about 510 ha of traditional apple varieties and about 170 ha of semi-dwarf apples. The remaining incremental irrigated areas would be planted in arable food and fodder crops. Together with existing irrigated areas, on which some changes in cropping patterns are expected to combine with yield improvements, the project at full development should to lead to net production increases on the order of 550 tons of fodder, 6,450 tons of arable crops, 3,270 tons of mixed orchard fruits and 14,200 tons of apples. Agricultural production from the development of the mini and flood schemes may increase these estimates by about 20 percent. 30. The economic internal rate of return for the development of the minor schemes is estimated at 14 percent. For an irrigation project, this might not appear to be a particularly strong result, but it is acceptable given the high costs of working with remote and scattered communities in Balochistan, and it appears to be robust. 31. Sensitivity Analysis. The economic rates of return are moderately sensitive to increases in scheme investments or project costs or to decreases in expected incremental production benefits. The following table shows that if increases in costs and decreases in benefits fall within a band of 20 percent, the project would still likely be acceptable.  - 113 - ANNEX 8 Page 13 Risks1' 32. The key issue in the sustainability of the development of the schemes is the role and perfornance of the farmer organizations. If a farmer organization were to operate effectively or fail, the implementation of its scheme would likely collapse or deteriorate rapidly for lack of proper routine maintenance. In high altitude areas, the economic consequences of this occurring might provide sufficient cohesion within groups to ensure that schemes do work. In other areas where the opportunity cost of failure might not be as high, there might not be as much confidence in the stability of groups. Due to importance of the organizational aspects of implementing and maintaining the irrigation works, village support services are a prominent component of the project. 33. Scheme location and distribution are critical to the economic justification of the project. Potentially, there may several low altitude areas where cropped area can be expanded, but per hectare, returns are higher for higher altitudes. If a larger proportion of low altitude schemes are built, the project might be much less economically desirable. The size and proportion of small schemes to large ones also has an expected bearing on the overall economic performance of the project. 34. The selection of suitable flood schemes is particularly difficult due to the complex sociology of the areas. Also, in these areas there are particular difficulties in estimating water flow and the market linkages, if not already present on a rudimentary scale, may be slow to develop. The return on the investment in the low altitude and flood scheme areas can be rather respectable since production in these areas would be improving from a low base. The success of the schemes, however, would depend on the ability of the project to provide the required extension assistance as needed and the willingness of farmers to accept the improvements afforded by available technologies. 35. The geographic spread of the schemes potentially under consideration may complicate project management and add to costs. To some extent, however, these difficulties have been anticipated; the establishment of several field offices under the project should help mitigate logistical difficulties. 36. The performance of contractors, which was a major constraint to the efficient, early implementation of the BMIAD, could also be a cause for concern. Strict post qualification and selection procedures that have been established in the later stages of BMIAD, along with rigorous monitoring have resulted in a small, but adequate pool of reasonably capable contractors. The risk of poor contractor performance under the present project still exists, but is considered now to have been much reduced. ] The following section draws from "Balochistan Minor Irrigation and Agricultural Development Project - Phase II, Project Preparation Report," Annex XXII, June 1993.

 - 117 - ANNEX 9 PAKISTAN BALOCEHISTAN COMMUNITY IRRIGATION AND AGRICULTURE PROJECT Project Implementation Plan A. The Project l. The project objectives are: (a) redefine government's role in minor irrigation development and provide assistance to facilitate change; (b) develop sustainable farmer organizations (FOs) which, amongst other things, can efficiently operate and maintain minor irrigation systems; (c) develop self-sustaining irrigation systems, and increase FO participation in their planning and construction; (d) increase beneficiaries' incomes and alleviate poverty; and (e) increase the recovery of public expenditures on irrigation infrastructure from beneficiaries. 2. The project components are: Community Development and Support (a) forming and developing FOs by providing technical assistance, data collection, guidance, legislation and training; (b) providing engineering, agricultural and other services to project beneficiaries; Infrastructure (c) designing, constructing and/or rehabilitating some 30 minor irrigation schemes, a pilot program of four flood irrigation schemes and, where possible, associated potable water supplies; Project Management (d) supporting a project management unit (PMU) within BID to implement the project by providing staff, technical assistance, training, equipment, vehicles, office space and operating funds. The PMU would include a community support group (CSG); (e) monitoring and evaluating project implementation through providing staff, technical assistance, vehicles, equipment, office space and operating funds;
 - 118 - ANNEX 9 Page 2 Agency Strengthening (f) strengthening BID's capabilities to interact with local communities and assist develop community planned and implemented minor irrigation by providing technical assistance and training, including implementing some eight mini irrigation schemes as part of in- service training; and (g) developing a pilot program to investigate how BID might generally transfer O&M responsibilities to FOs of all minor irrigation schemes outside this project or BMIAD. 3. Cost Estimates. GOBal would fully implement the project over seven years. The IDA credit would assist finance the project over the first five years. For this period the total estimated project cost is US$38.5 million, of which US$11.9 million is the foreign exchange costs. GOBal with GON assistance would finance all project costs (US$1.5 million) during year six and seven. 4. Financing. IDA, GON, GOBal and local community farmers and households would jointly finance the project. IDA would provide a credit of SDR 18.5 million (US$26.7 million), GON a grant of NLG 8.5 million (US$5.4 million), local community farmers and households Rs 92.4 million (US$2.6 million), of which roughly Rs 47.6 million would be in cash and Rs 44.8 million in labor, and GOBal the remaining Rs 135.1 million (US$3.8 million). IDA's credit would finance 69% of project costs, including 77 % of foreign exchange costs and 66% of local costs. Excluding duties and taxes, IDA and GON together would finance 90% of project costs. B. Implementation Arrangements 5. General. BID, through its PMU and in association with FOs and DOA, would be responsible for implementing the project. GOBal would establish a project steering committee to determine overall project policy, assist with coordination and regularly review implementation. The Additional Chief Secretary, P&D, would chair the committee which would include, among others the Secretaries of Finance, Irrigation, Agriculture, Livestock, Health and Public Health Engineering, Member, Board of Revenue and the Project Director. The steering committee would meet twice a year, or more often if necessary, and would approve scheme selection, designs, workplans and budgets. PMU would act as the committee's secretariat, and would prepare its agenda and monitor its decisions. 6. BID's Role. While BID's Secretary would be ultimately responsible for project operations, PMU's Project Director would be the day-to-day project manager and PMU's three groups, together with FOs, would plan, design and implement the project. To allow PMU undertake its responsibilities, BID would enlarge, strengthen and reorganize it including seconding senior and other staff to it. However, following completion of the final aftercare period (project year seven), BID would disband PMU and bring the responsibilities for community irrigation development back into BID's regular work programs. To prepare for this, PMU's PDS would assist BID's management to formulate and implement a staff training strategy including management and business plans, BID circle staff, with assistance from PMU, would implement eight mini irrigation schemes, and PMU staff would assist BID staff plan and implement a pilot program to transfer O&M responsibilities to FOs.

In~~~ernenta1 Salaties~~~~~~~~ 0LT~~~~IK. ...... . . . . ... .... 13 ........ 2.2..... ~~~~~~~~~~~... .. . . .. ... - .......... .. ...... . . ... ... . .. . ..........- rexnental Q&M Costs :~~~~~~~~~~~~:.:U: .: ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ..3 .. .. 7. PMU would liaise with and be IDA's main contact concerning project implementation, and would monitor overall project progress. It would prepare and submit to IDA half-yearly project reports which would update and assess imnplementation of project components during the previous six months. PMU and IDA would agree on the report format by end-November 1995, and PMU would forward the reports to IDA within two months from the end of each six-month period, beginning with the semester ending December 31, 1995. PMU would ensure that all credit disbursement applications are sent to IDA. Within six months of credit completion, PMU would contribute to a project implementation completion report, reporting on all aspects of the project. 8. DOA's Role. DOA will second six of its regular staff to PMU's CSG. These will be agricultural officer level (AO)(BPS-17) extension staff, preferably with horticultural experience. CSG will station them in its four field offices, and they will be an integral part of CSG's agricultural planning, operations and extension programs. DOA field assistants (FAs) stationed in or near the irrigation scheme areas would assist AOs implement the project's extension program. To enable FAs to be involved in project activities, the project would provide DOA 50 motorcycles, and FAs a travel allowance when visiting project farmers. 9. Individual Scheme Implementation. Besides scheme development applications already received during project preparation, PMU will advertise the project again in the media immediately after project commencement. PMU's PDA and CSG staff would screen and select suitable community schemes. Selected communities must agree to project conditions, including establishing formal FOs, opening CD and O&M accounts at a local bank and making an initial deposit into the CD account. CSG social organizers would assist commnunities form and develop their FOs. Concurrently the Project Director and the FO, in the presence of the Deputy Commissioner, would sign a scheme agreement which would detail the obligations and responsibilities of both the project and FO.
 - 120 - ANNEX 9 Page 4 10. PDS, in consultation with FO and inputs from CSG, would design scheme works. Following FO approval of the works, and deposit of the required FO member funds in its CD account, PMU would tender and award the main works. Following satisfactory completion of the main works, FO would assume full O&M responsibility for the works. A two year aftercare period would then commence during which FO, with CSG engineering staff assistance, would decide CAD works required and construct them. Additionally, over the five to six years following completion of the main works, in addition to earlier capital cost payments deposited into its bank accounts, FO would repay another 8 or 15% in real terms of the scheme's capital cost. FO would collect the annual repayments from its members. These funds would be used for high priority local development priorities. Following the successful completion of these payments, BID would transfer to FO ownership of the constructed works. 11. Social Development Program. CSG's social development staff would consist of an internationally recruited social scientist (24 sm), a locally recruited social scientist (40 sm), a directly hired farmer organization specialist and two directly hired women social organizers (one senior position, one junior position) in the field support staff at Quetta; and two male farmer (social) organizers (one senior) and one female social organizer at each field office (total of 12 social organizers in field offices). During scheme screening, the social organizers would explain the project concept, rights and obligations to community leaders and members. To undertake screening studies, they would live in the community village area for about two weeks and collect data on community population, occupations, wealth and income distribution, water and land rights distribution, occurrence of disputes, existing cropping patterns and yields, livestock ownership, women's tasks, health and so on. When project staff and the community decide to develop a proposed scheme, the social organizers would assist the community establish and operate a formal FO, and act as an interface between the community and other project and government staff. The social organizers, in particular, would assist FO develop its financial activities concerning scheme financing, cost recovery and O&M. They would help FO organize its members to undertake its responsibilities under the project, for example, receiving training from CSG staff, undertaking PMU contract work, and contracting out CAD works. They would assist FO members with dispute mediation. Women social organizers would assist community women establish and operate WGs, provide PWS O&M and health and hygiene training, and organize appropriate agricultural training for women. The social organizers, along with other CSG staff, would be involved in project monitoring. The internationally recruited social scientist, along with the senior women social organizer, would lead, plan and supervise the team's program. At project commencement, an NGO such as BRSP would train the social organizers (both male and female) in group formation, social assessment and other aspects of their work. 12. Water Management Program. CSG's water management team would consist of an internationally recruited land and water management specialist (19 sm) and, directly hired, a senior water management engineer and two CAD design engineers, in the field support staff at Quetta; and one water management and one farmer support engineer in each field office. During the scheme aftercare period, the field office water management engineer would advise and assist FO members identify the CAD works required to handle the increased discharges from the improved main works. He/she would undertake trials and demonstrations of alternative low-cost canal lining, and improved water management and application methods. The engineer would also train FO members in water management, and O&M of the whole system. The farmer support engineer would assist and supervise FO members in their CAD construction. The CAD design engineers would design the agreed CAD works, while the senior water management engineer would assist, review and supervise the CAD design work. The land and water management specialist would advise on and undertake on-farm research of alternative low-cost canal lining and simple, improved water handling techniques at the canal and field levels.
 - 121 - ANNEX 9 Page 5 13. Agricultural Development Program. CSG's agricultural development staff would consist of an internationally recruited agricultural extension specialist (12 sm), a locally recruited agricultural extension specialist (36 sm), and two directly hired extension subject matter specialists (SMS) in the field support staff at Quetta; six AOs stationed throughout the field offices; some 50 DOA FAs located in or near scheme areas; and some 45-60 VDAs, one per FO. The internationally recruited agricultural economist located with PDS would assist the team with advice on crop gross margins, crop prices and marketing data, profitability of current and potential cropping patterns and other matters. Immediately at scheme screening and detailed design the agricultural staff (particularly the extension specialist, agricultural economist, SMS and AOs) would meet and discuss with farmers potential best use of additional water, and possible impacts this might have on scheine design. This would, of course. be continued during the first year of aftercare when choice of cropping pattern could strongly dictate CAD works required. Once FO members have decided their cropping patterns, the team would advise them on varieties, best appropriate production methods, harvesting, marketing and storage. The team would stage field days and demonstrations, undertake appropriate on-farm research, and produce suitable extension leaflets, videos or other material. The agricultural extension expert. along with SMSs, would lead, plan and supervise the team's program. After scheme construction, AOs, assisted by FAs, would regularly visit FOs at least monthly and give advice and help and arrange training concerning farmer's priority problems. The team would encourage each FO to nominate a person from their community to be trained to work as a first level extension agent or VDA. VDAs would be the team's main contact with FOs, and should have a positive personality, be respected in the community and be a farmer although in some cases a local school teacher or such person may be suitable. If possible, FO members should remunerate VDA for his services. As stated, BRSP would give VDA their initial training, while the project would provide considerable in-service training for AOs and other team members. 14. Project Monitoring. Monitoring of the project would be "management oriented", that is, designed to provide information to assist internal project management. PMU's MIS section would monitor and analyze project activities at four levels, that is, project inputs (number of staff hired, vehicles, material procured and so on); outputs (headworks, canals, CAD works constructed); effects or success in meeting project objectives (use easily identifiable and measurable indicators such as crop yields or increased orchard or other crops planted); and long-term project impacts such as increased farrner incomes. The internationally recruited monitoring and evaluation (M&E) specialist (7 sm) would assist MIS section, and overall project staff, design and implement appropriate monitoring systems. This would require a meeting of all project management staff to decide what should be monitored, what indicators used, who collects information and who receives, and to set annual work targets. MIS should monitor and analyze long-term project impacts through case studies, not large project-wide surveys. MIS would have a complaints officer to whom FO or community members could bring complaints concerning project implementation, and have them dealt with in a transparent manner. 15. IDA's Role. While IDA would supervise the project at more than average rates during the initial year. from then on IDA would use normal supervision inputs. This higher rate of supervision during project start-up is justified because of the project's importance in initiating GOBal and tDA's new irrigation development strategy. During the project's first full implementation years (July 1995 to June 1996), IDA would use approximately 21 sw for all supervision activities, 16 sw in the second year, and about 14-15 sw for each of the remaining years. 16. To facilitate project start-up, IDA along with BID and PMU would organize and hold a project launch workshop soon after credit signing. The workshop would familiarize implementation staff
 - 122 - ANNEX 9 Page 6 with project objectives, components and other administrative aspects. BID, DOA, IDA (with FAO Country Program staff), BRSP and other appropriate NGOs would undertake two interim evaluations of the project, the first no later than September 30, 1997, and the second by September 30, 1999. C. Implementation Plan 17. Tables 2 and 3 detail project implementation regarding institutional development. Table 2 lists the institutions the project will strengthen, and their objectives and responsibilities. Table 3 shows the yearly implementation of this strengthening with regard to component inputs, outputs and indicators of effects or success.

doc.repnme: Pakistan - Balochistan Community Irrigation and Agriculture Project
doc.abstracts: The Balochistan Community Irrigation and Agriculture Project initiates implementation of the Governments of Pakistan and Balochistan's new irrigation and drainage strategy for developing efficient, sustainable minor irrigation. In doing this, it undertakes interrelated actions to greatly increase community involvement in project development, financing and operation so as to increase beneficiaries' ownership and commitment to project works, and lead to the efficient and ustainable use of reousreces. These actions are in three broad areas, that is, developing and strengthening community organizations so they can assist, plan and construct minor irrigation systems and assume full responsibility for operating them; constructing appropriate irrigation infrastructure which beneficiaries would be prepared to properly operate and maintain; changing and strengthening the Balochistan Irrigation Department's capabilities so it can assist communities to eventually take a leading role in developing their minor irrigation resources.
